profile></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Improving the performance and reliability of GitLab.com has always been a top priority for GitLab. While we continuously make iterative improvements to GitLab and our production architecture, we anticipate making a larger change to improve the scalability and reliability of GitLab.com: We are splitting our single PostgreSQL database into a main and a cidatabase.></android.view.View__Improving the performance and reliability of GitLab.com has always been a top priority for GitLab. While we continuously make iterative improvements to GitLab and our production architecture, we anticipate making a larger change to improve the scalability and reliability of GitLab.com: We are splitting our single PostgreSQL database into a main and a cidatabase.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__We believe this process, also known as ></android.view.View__We believe this process, also known as ><android.view.View__functional decomposition></android.view.View__functional decomposition><android.view.View__, will increase GitLab's database capacity by roughly 2x and allows GitLab.com to continue to scale.></android.view.View__, will increase GitLab's database capacity by roughly 2x and allows GitLab.com to continue to scale.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__When will the split take place and what does this mean for users of GitLab.com?></android.view.View__When will the split take place and what does this mean for users of GitLab.com?><android.view.View__This change is planned to take place between Saturday, 2022-07-02, 05:00am UTC and Saturday, 2022-07-02, 09:00am UTC. The implementation of this change is anticipated to include a service downtime of up to 120 minutesbetween Saturday, 2022-07-02, 06:00am to 08:00am UTC. During this time you will experience complete service disruption of GitLab.com.></android.view.View__This change is planned to take place between Saturday, 2022-07-02, 05:00am UTC and Saturday, 2022-07-02, 09:00am UTC. The implementation of this change is anticipated to include a service downtime of up to 120 minutesbetween Saturday, 2022-07-02, 06:00am to 08:00am UTC. During this time you will experience complete service disruption of GitLab.com.><android.view.View__We are taking downtime to ensure that the application works as expected following the split and to minimize the risk of any data integrity issues.></android.view.View__We are taking downtime to ensure that the application works as expected following the split and to minimize the risk of any data integrity issues.><android.view.View__Background></android.view.View__Background><android.view.View__><android.view.View__GitLab.com's ></android.view.View__GitLab.com's ><android.view.View__database architecture></android.view.View__database architecture><android.view.View__ uses a single PostgreSQL database cluster. This single cluster (let's call it ></android.view.View__ uses a single PostgreSQL database cluster. This single cluster (let's call it ><android.view.View__main></android.view.View__main><android.view.View__), consists of a single primary and multiple read-only replicas and stores the data generated by all GitLab features. Database reads can be scaled horizontally through read-only replicas, but writes cannot because PostgreSQL does not support active-active replication natively.></android.view.View__), consists of a single primary and multiple read-only replicas and stores the data generated by all GitLab features. Database reads can be scaled horizontally through read-only replicas, but writes cannot because PostgreSQL does not support active-active replication natively.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__A large portion of all writes are generated by features related to Continuous Integration (CI). So, to scale GitLab.com's database capacity, we are splitting the single PostgreSQL main cluster into two clusters:></android.view.View__A large portion of all writes are generated by features related to Continuous Integration (CI). So, to scale GitLab.com's database capacity, we are splitting the single PostgreSQL main cluster into two clusters:><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__A Continuous Integration database cluster for all CI-related features (ci).><android.view.View__1></android.view.View__1><android.view.View__A Continuous Integration database cluster for all CI-related features (><android.view.View__ci></android.view.View__ci><android.view.View__).></android.view.View__).></android.view.View__A Continuous Integration database cluster for all CI-related features (ci).><android.view.View__A database cluster for all other features (main).><android.view.View__2></android.view.View__2><android.view.View__A database cluster for all other features (></android.view.View__A database cluster for all other features (><android.view.View__main></android.view.View__main><android.view.View__).></android.view.View__).></android.view.View__A database cluster for all other features (main).></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__At a high level, GitLab.com's database architecture is changing like this:></android.view.View__At a high level, GitLab.com's database architecture is changing like this:><android.widget.Image__Illustration of splitting into Main and CI></android.widget.Image__Illustration of splitting into Main and page><android.view.View__ or by visiting our public epic: ></android.view.View__ or by visiting our public epic: ><android.view.View__Decompose GitLab.com's database to improve scalability></android.view.View__Decompose GitLab.com's database to improve into ></android.view.View__Splitting our database into ><android.view.View__main></android.view.View__main><android.view.View__ and ></android.view.View__ and ><android.view.View__ci></android.view.View__ci><android.view.View__ initially will only impact GitLab.com. To ensure consistency, we plan to enable ></android.view.View__ initially will only impact GitLab.com. To ensure consistency, we plan to enable ><android.view.View__decomposition for self-managed GitLab instances></android.view.View__decomposition for self-managed GitLab instances><android.view.View__ later. While this split is a significant architectural change that we believe will increase GitLab's database capacity by roughly 2x, there are other benefits as well.></android.view.View__ later. While this split is a significant architectural change that we believe will increase GitLab's database capacity by roughly 2x, there are other benefits as well.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Increased performance></android.view.View__Increased performance><android.view.View__By running two separate database clusters, we believe we will increase the overall count of available database connections. This means we can serve more traffic. It also means that during peak hours there is more buffer, which reduces the likelihood of congestion that may cause performance and UX degradations.></android.view.View__By running two separate database clusters, we believe we will increase the overall count of available database connections. This means we can serve more traffic. It also means that during peak hours there is more buffer, which reduces the likelihood of congestion that may cause performance and UX degradations.><android.view.View__Another significant advantage is that we anticipate we will be able to tune the main andci databases independently, allowing us to optimize these different workloads.></android.view.View__Another significant advantage is that we anticipate we will be able to tune the main andci databases independently, allowing us to optimize these different workloads.><android.view.View__Increased stability></android.view.View__Increased stability><android.view.View__Splitting the database cluster into main and cimeans that ci writes are shifting to the cidatabase cluster. We anticipate this will lead to reduced database saturation, which is a major cause of incidents. Consequently, we believe that the overall stability of GitLab.com may increase following the split.></android.view.View__Splitting the database cluster into main and cimeans that ci writes are shifting to the cidatabase cluster. We anticipate this will lead to reduced database saturation, which is a major cause of incidents. Consequently, we believe that the overall stability of GitLab.com may increase following the split.><android.view.View__We believe increased stability means that development teams can spend more time working on generating value through new features and other improvements and less time guarding against potential issues.></android.view.View__We believe increased stability means that development teams can spend more time working on generating value through new features and other improvements and less time guarding against potential issues.><android.view.View__Shipping as fast as ever></android.view.View__Shipping as fast as ever><android.view.View__><android.view.View__A primary objective of this project was to provide tooling to our development teams so that they can continue to develop features that use multiple databases. All of these tools, for example ></android.view.View__A primary objective of this project was to provide tooling to our development teams so that they can continue to develop features that use multiple databases. All of these tools, for example ><android.view.View__loose foreign keys></android.view.View__loose foreign keys><android.view.View__ or new ></android.view.View__ or new ><android.view.View__data migrations for multiple databases></android.view.View__data migrations for multiple databases><android.view.View__, are available already and used in production.></android.view.View__, are available already and used in production.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__With these tools in place, we expect that teams will be able to ship features as fast as before.></android.view.View__With these tools in place, we expect that teams will be able to ship features as fast as before.><android.view.View__Tools and dashboards re-use></android.view.View__Tools and dashboards re-use><android.view.View__This change does introduce additional complexity. After all, we will run another database cluster. Given that the ci cluster is almost identical to the existing main cluster, our DBREs and SREs are able to re-use almost all tools (for example for backups) and dashboards. This reduces the overall risk introduced by this change.></android.view.View__This change does introduce additional complexity. After all, we will run another database cluster. Given that the ci cluster is almost identical to the existing main cluster, our DBREs and SREs are able to re-use almost all tools (for example for backups) and dashboards. This reduces the overall risk introduced by this change.><android.view.View__How we are preparing for the split></android.view.View__How we are preparing for the split><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Over the last year, many teams at GitLab have worked to support running GitLab using multiple databases. These rehearsals include dry runs, executing the promotion of the ><android.view.View__ci></android.view.View__ci><android.view.View__ database cluster, and testing our rollback strategies. All of these steps are tracked as part of a CI decomposition change template. This template is continuously improved to ensure that we capture all learnings from the rehearsals. The template is mirrored onto our Ops GitLab instance, which will remain available during the downtime window and forms the basis for executing the change.></android.view.View__ database cluster, and testing our rollback strategies. YOU probably shouldn't use Kubernetes and a bunch of other "cool" things for your product.><android.view.View__Most folks building software at startups and scale-ups should avoid Kubernetes and other premature optimisations. If your company uses Kubernetes, you are likely expending energy on something that doesn't take you towards your mission. You have probably fallen into the trap of premature optimisation.></android.view.View__Most folks building software at startups and scale-ups should avoid Kubernetes and other premature optimisations. If your company uses Kubernetes, you are likely expending energy on something that doesn't take you towards your mission. You have probably fallen into the trap of premature optimisation.><android.view.View__Please don't take this post to be only aimed against Kubernetes. It is not. I am directing this post at every possible bit of premature optimisation engineers make in the course of building software.></android.view.View__Please don't take this post to be only aimed against Kubernetes. It is not. I am directing this post at every possible bit of premature optimisation engineers make in the course of building software.><android.view.View__Here are a few examples I've seen:></android.view.View__Here are a few examples I've seen:><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__Companies using Kubernetes for an application that is a web app.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__Companies using Kubernetes for an application that is a web app.></android.view.View__Companies using Kubernetes for an application that is a web app.></android.view.View__Companies using Kubernetes for an application that is a web app.><android.view.View__More than one language for your application. Most product teams will have over-architected their solution if they have to have an ops or infra team.></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__Imagine spending a lot of time and money picking out the best possible gear for a hobby before actually starting the hobby.></android.view.View__Imagine spending a lot of time and money picking out the best possible gear for a hobby before actually starting the hobby.><android.view.View__Some of this is subjective, of course. Perhaps you know you will stick with your new hobby for a long time, and you have a friend who is an expert at your new hobby who can help you pick the right gear. I have to admit I'm good at justifying the elite-level equipment for myself, even though I might never really notice the difference.></android.view.View__Some of this is subjective, of course. Perhaps you know you will stick with your new hobby for a long time, and you have a friend who is an expert at your new hobby who can help you pick the right gear. I have to admit I'm good at justifying the elite-level equipment for myself, even though I might never really notice the difference.><android.view.View__Your organisation needs engineers to create an impact on the mission.></android.view.View__Your organisation needs engineers to create an impact on the mission.><android.view.View__If you are in a place where you think you need Kubernetes, then you are probably in a place where you are trying to optimise for the future prematurely. A future that probably won't happen. If you adopt any technology, you are making a multi-year commitment for your organisation that will increase the surface area of your product and the cognitive load on your developers. Eventually, you will have to create a dedicated team to maintain it. All of this takes resources away from your core mission.></android.view.View__If you are in a place where you think you need Kubernetes, then you are probably in a place where you are trying to optimise for the future prematurely. A future that probably won't happen. If you adopt any technology, you are making a multi-year commitment for your organisation that will increase the surface area of your product and the cognitive load on your developers. Eventually, you will have to create a dedicated team to maintain it. All of this takes resources away from your core mission.><android.view.View__It is easy for engineers to slip into this trap. We are all magpies distracted by the new shiny. We want to learn and grow, and the best way to do that is to incorporate the latest tech into our product. Then, we can come up with all sorts of reasons that justify our decisions.></android.view.View__It is easy for engineers to slip into this trap. We are all magpies distracted by the new shiny. We want to learn and grow, and the best way to do that is to incorporate the latest tech into our product. Then, we can come up with all sorts of reasons that justify our decisions.><android.view.View__Let me tell you some stories of how I have fallen into this trap.></android.view.View__Let me tell you some stories of how I have fallen into this trap.><android.view.View__I remember a discussion when I joined OCUS and discovered we were using Kubernetes. I said something to the tune of, "oh, that is great. One day, we might want to leave AWS and having Kubernetes will help us with that". Can you see how crazy I was at that moment?></android.view.View__I remember a discussion when I joined OCUS and discovered we were using Kubernetes. I said something to the tune of, "oh, that is great. One day, we might want to leave AWS and having Kubernetes will help us with that". Can you see how crazy I was at that moment?><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Another time our Data Science team told us that they needed an orchestration tool for their data pipelines. I steered the selection process towards ></android.view.View__Another time our Data Science team told us that they needed an orchestration tool for their data pipelines. I steered the selection process towards ><android.view.View__Argo Workflows></android.view.View__Argo Workflows><android.view.View__(which runs inside Kubernetes) instead of ></android.view.View__(which runs inside Kubernetes) instead of ><android.view.View__Prefect></android.view.View__Prefect><android.view.View__ (a SaaS offering), which they already used for a PoC. There were all sorts of justifications in my head for this decision. Unfortunately, they were all based on premature optimisations. In the end, our team needed to build a new set of Terraform and Helm charts to automate the deployment of Argo Workflows and integrate it into our SSO etc. I regret this decision. I think we lost weeks or even months shipping something to end-users because of this decision. Premature optimisation!></android.view.View__ (a SaaS offering), which they already used for a PoC. There were all sorts of justifications in my head for this decision. Unfortunately, they were all based on premature optimisations. In the end, our team needed to build a new set of Terraform and Helm charts to automate the deployment of Argo Workflows and integrate it into our SSO etc. I regret this decision. I think we lost weeks or even months shipping something to end-users because of this decision. Premature optimisation!></android.view.View__><android.view.View__If we can dodge premature optimisations, we will move faster than our competitors, please our users and increase our chances of building a sustainable and viable product.></android.view.View__If we can dodge premature optimisations, we will move faster than our competitors, please our users and increase our chances of building a sustainable and viable product.><android.view.View__So how can we break out of this thinking?></android.view.View__So how can we break out of this thinking?><android.view.View__Did users ask for this?></android.view.View__Did users ask for this?><android.view.View__Solve problems as they arise, not in advance. The work we do should solve the user's issues. Ask yourself,what is the human behaviour I'm trying to impact with my work?></android.view.View__Solve problems as they arise, not in advance. The work we do should solve the user's issues. Ask yourself,what is the human behaviour I'm trying to impact with my work?><android.view.View__If you can remain laser-focused on impacting user behaviour and only solve real problems when they come up, you will surprise yourself with the impact you can have. You might also surprise yourself with how many assumptions you make about users because you haven't talked to them in a long time.></android.view.View__If you can remain laser-focused on impacting user behaviour and only solve real problems when they come up, you will surprise yourself with the impact you can have. You might also surprise yourself with how many assumptions you make about users because you haven't talked to them in a long time.><android.view.View__I believe that companies that stick to this approach rigorously will create greater leverage and more value for their users and shareholders.></android.view.View__I believe that companies that stick to this approach rigorously will create greater leverage and more value for their users and shareholders.><android.view.View__I will know what I need if I spend all my energy doing my new hobby instead of researching equipment. In the beginning stages, I will not need the most "Gucci" gear, and I might even look out of place if I had the best equipment and no clue how to use it. It would be better to smash others with my entry-level equipment down the line because I spent all my energy learning my new hobby. Then when I did upgrade to the "Gucci" gear, it would make a real difference.></android.view.View__I will know what I need if I spend all my energy doing my new hobby instead of researching equipment. In the beginning stages, I will not need the most "Gucci" gear, and I might even look out of place if I had the best equipment and no clue how to use it. It would be better to smash others with my entry-level equipment down the line because I spent all my energy learning my new hobby. Then when I did upgrade to the "Gucci" gear, it would make a real difference.><android.view.View__Do more with less.></android.view.View__Do more with less.><android.view.View__Thankfully the Tech world is going through a massive course correction. As interest rates increase, cheap debt and Venture Capital is starting to dry up. Now that startups can't access crazy money, they must focus even more on their mission. The companies that survive will be the ones that have solid fundamentals.></android.view.View__Thankfully the Tech world is going through a massive course correction. As interest rates increase, cheap debt and Venture Capital is starting to dry up. Now that startups can't access crazy money, they must focus even more on their mission. The companies that survive will be the ones that have solid fundamentals.><android.view.View__Products will have to be built by smaller teams that can deliver business outcomes at an increasingly faster pace.></android.view.View__Products will have to be built by smaller teams that can deliver business outcomes at an increasingly faster pace.><android.view.View__I can't see a place for Kubernetes in a lean organisation until they have grown to a massive scale. Even then, I think Kubernetes is a stretch. Most organisations should consider some of the higher-level building blocks available via cloud providers.></android.view.View__I can't see a place for Kubernetes in a lean organisation until they have grown to a massive scale. Even then, I think Kubernetes is a stretch. Most organisations should consider some of the higher-level building blocks available via cloud providers.><android.view.View__Remember that when Facebook bought WhatsApp for $19 billion, it had 35 developers and 450 million users!></android.view.View__Remember that when Facebook bought WhatsApp for $19 billion, it had 35 developers and 450 million users!><android.view.View__If there is one takeaway from reading this, it is to be hyper-focused on what you need to achieve your organisation's mission. Don't get distracted by stuff you want to learn like Kubernetes or Golang - save that for the homelab.></android.view.View__If there is one takeaway from reading this, it is to be hyper-focused on what you need to achieve your organisation's mission. Podman is a daemonless container engine for developing, managing, and running OCI Containers on your Linux System. Containers can either be run as root or in rootless mode. Simply put: alias docker=podman. When run without root, Podman containers use user namespaces to set root in the container to the user running Podman. Rootless Podman runs locked-down containers with no privileges that the user running the container does not have. Some of these restrictions can be lifted (via --privileged, for example), but rootless containers will never have more privileges than the user that launched them. If you run Podman as your user and mount in /etc/passwd from the host, you still won't be able to change it, since your user doesn't have permission to do so.', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=213, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=214, n='android.view.View', t='Almost all normal Podman functionality is available, though there are some ', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=215, n='android.view.View', t='shortcomings', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=216, n='android.view.View', t='. Both, Buildah and Podman are command line tools that work on Open Container Initiative (OCI) images and containers. The two projects differentiate in their specialization.', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=338, n='android.view.View', t='Buildah specializes in building OCI images. Buildah's commands replicate all of the commands that are found in a Dockerfile. This allows building images with and without Dockerfiles while not requiring any root privileges. Buildah’s ultimate goal is to provide a lower-level coreutils interface to build images. The flexibility of building images without Dockerfiles allows for the integration of other scripting languages into the build process. Buildah follows a simple fork-exec model and does not run as a daemon but it is based on a comprehensive API in golang, which can be vendored into other tools.', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=339, n='android.view.View', t='Podman specializes in all of the commands and functions that help you to maintain and modify OCI images, such as pulling and tagging. It also allows you to create, run, and maintain those containers created from those images. For building container images via Dockerfiles, Podman uses Buildah's golang API and can be installed independently from Buildah.', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=340, n='android.view.View', t='A major difference between Podman and Buildah is their concept of a container. Podman allows users to create "traditional containers" where the intent of these containers is to be long lived. While Buildah containers are really just created to allow content to be added back to the container image. An easy way to think of it is the buildah run command emulates the RUN command in a Dockerfile while the podman run command emulates the docker run command in functionality. Because of this and their underlying storage differences, you can not see Podman containers from within Buildah or vice versa.', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=341, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=342, n='android.view.View', t='In short, Buildah is an efficient way to create OCI images while Podman allows you to manage and maintain those images and containers in a production environment using familiar container cli commands. For more details, see the', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=343, n='android.view.View', t='Container Tools Guide', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=344, n='android.view.View', t='.', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=345, n='android.view.View', t='Podman Hello', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=346, n='android.view.View', t='Podman Hello', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=347, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=348, n='android.view.View', t='$ podman run quay.io/podman/hello

Let’s say that we’d want it to run tasks that we need to complete, providing the OS hardware resources. Tasks come of different natures but we can simply categorize them as CPU-intensive and interactive ones.', ix=''}, comp{id=152, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Something should provide the efficiency of task completion and responsiveness. Consider a typewriter that prints letters with 1s second of delay, it would be impossible to use! So, in a few words, I would like to request to the scheduler: “I want to execute this task and I want it’s completed when I need or to respond when I need”. The goal of a scheduler is to decide “what runs next” leading to have the best balance between the needings of the different natures of the tasks.', ix=''}, comp{id=153, n='android.view.View', t='', d='As Linux is a preemptive multitasking operating system, the completely fair scheduler (CFS) came to Linux, as the replacement of the O(1) scheduler from the 2.6.23, with the aim to guarantee the fairness of CPU owning by the tasks, and at the same time tailoring to a broad nature range of tasks. Although the algorithm complexity didn’t see an improvement, from O(1) to O(log N), the reduced latency removed issues when dealing with interactive tasks.', ix=''}, comp{id=154, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=155, n='android.view.View', t='', d='As a side note consider that the Linux scheduler is made of different ', ix=''}, comp{id=156, n='android.view.View', t='', d='scheduler classes', ix=''}, comp{id=157, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' (', ix=''}, comp{id=158, n='android.view.View', t='', d='code', ix=''}, comp{id=159, n='android.view.View', t='', d='), of which the ', ix=''}, comp{id=160, n='android.view.View', t='', d='CFS class', ix=''}, comp{id=161, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' is the highest-priority one. n='android.view.View', t='', d='is not scaled', ix=''}, comp{id=483, n='android.view.View', t='', d='.', ix=''}, comp{id=484, n='android.view.View', t='', d='In detail, the load is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group or the task group’s runqueue.', ix=''}, comp{id=485, n='android.view.View', t='', d='shares = shares * (runqueue's load / task group's load)
', ix=''}, comp{id=486, n='android.view.View', t='', d='TL;DR: the ratio is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the runqueues to the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group:', ix=''}, comp{id=487, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=488, n='android.view.View', t='', d='The calculcation is done by the', ix=''}, comp{id=489, n='android.view.View', t='', d='calc_group_shares()', ix=''}, comp{id=490, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' function, to get the final value of the task group’s shares that will weight the virtual runtime of the task group schedule entity:', ix=''}, comp{id=491, n='android.view.View', t='', d='static long calc_group_shares(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
{
	long tg_weight, tg_shares, load, shares;
	/
	struct task_group *tg = cfs_rq->tg;

	/*
	   tg_shares is the task group's CPU shares.
	 */
	tg_shares = READ_ONCE(tg->shares);

	/*
	   load is the load of the local CFS runqueue which is,
	   the load of the task group on the local CPU.
	 */
	load = max(scale_load_down(cfs_rq->load.weight), cfs_rq->avg.load_avg);

	/*
	   tg_weight is the global load of the task group.
	 */
	tg_weight = atomic_long_read(&tg->load_avg);

	/* Ensure tg_weight >= load */
	tg_weight -= cfs_rq->tg_load_avg_contrib;
	tg_weight += load;

	shares = (tg_shares * load);
	if (tg_weight)
		shares /= tg_weight;

	// ...

	/*
	   shares is now the per CPU-scaled task group shares.
	*/
	return clamp_t(long, shares, MIN_SHARES, tg_shares);
}

	if (tg_weight)
		shares /= tg_weight;

 * Called by the timer interrupt handler every 1/HZ seconds.
 */
scheduler_tick()
/* The local CPU */
-> int cpu = smp_processor_id();
/* The local CPU runqueue */
-> struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
/* The local CPU runqueue currently running task */
-> struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
/* The current running task's scheduler class' periodic tick function. */
-> curr->sched_class->task_tick(rq, curr)
   /* Let's assume the class is CFS. */
   -> task_tick_fair()
      -> struct sched_entity *se = &curr->se;
      /*
       * For each schedule entity through parent task groups
       * up to the root task group.
       */
      -> for_each_sched_entity(se)
         /* The runqueue where the entity is placed. */
         -> cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
         -> entity_tick(cfs_rq, se)
            /*
             * Update the virtual runtime for the current running entity
             * on the current selected by loop-task group's runqueue.
             */
            -> update_curr(cfs_rq)
               -> struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
               -> delta_exec = now - curr->exec_start;
               -> curr->exec_start = now;
               -> curr->vruntime += calc_delta_fair(delta_exec, curr);
            /*
             * If it's a task group update the shares 
             * based on its group runqueue,
             * which is the group load on the local CPU
             */
            -> update_cfs_group(se)
               /* The CFS runqueue of the entity, if it's a task group. */
               -> struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
               /* If the entity is a task, skip */
               -> if (!gcfs_rq)
               ->   return;
               /*
                * Update the CPU shares for the task group entity.
                */
               -> shares = calc_group_shares(gcfs_rq);
               -> reweight_entity(cfs_rq_of(se), se, shares);

up></android.view.View__Wrapping up></android.view.View__></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__1. Resource sharing is the key!></android.view.View__1. Resource sharing is the key!><android.view.View__Let’s dive into the Linux component which is responsible for doing such great work: the scheduler.></android.view.View__Let’s dive into the Linux component which is responsible for doing such great work: the scheduler.><android.view.View__In order to do it, imagine what we would expect from an operating system. Let’s say that we’d want it to run tasks that we need to complete, providing the OS hardware resources. Tasks come of different natures but we can simply categorize them as CPU-intensive and interactive ones.></android.view.View__In order to do it, imagine what we would expect from an operating system. Let’s say that we’d want it to run tasks that we need to complete, providing the OS hardware resources. Tasks come of different natures but we can simply categorize them as CPU-intensive and interactive ones.><android.view.View__Something should provide the efficiency of task completion and responsiveness. Consider a typewriter that prints letters with 1s second of delay, it would be impossible to use! So, in a few words, I would like to request to the scheduler: “I want to execute this task and I want it’s completed when I need or to respond when I need”. The goal of a scheduler is to decide “what runs next” leading to have the best balance between the needings of the different natures of the tasks.></android.view.View__Something should provide the efficiency of task completion and responsiveness. Consider a typewriter that prints letters with 1s second of delay, it would be impossible to use! So, in a few words, I would like to request to the scheduler: “I want to execute this task and I want it’s completed when I need or to respond when I need”. The goal of a scheduler is to decide “what runs next” leading to have the best balance between the needings of the different natures of the tasks.><android.view.View__As Linux is a preemptive multitasking operating system, the completely fair scheduler (CFS) came to Linux, as the replacement of the O(1) scheduler from the 2.6.23, with the aim to guarantee the fairness of CPU owning by the tasks, and at the same time tailoring to a broad nature range of tasks. Although the algorithm complexity didn’t see an improvement, from O(1) to O(log N), the reduced latency removed issues when dealing with interactive tasks.></android.view.View__As Linux is a preemptive multitasking operating system, the completely fair scheduler (CFS) came to Linux, as the replacement of the O(1) scheduler from the 2.6.23, with the aim to guarantee the fairness of CPU owning by the tasks, and at the same time tailoring to a broad nature range of tasks. Although the algorithm complexity didn’t see an improvement, from O(1) to O(log N), the reduced latency removed issues when dealing with interactive tasks.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__As a side note consider that the Linux scheduler is made of different ></android.view.View__As a side note consider that the Linux scheduler is made of different ><android.view.View__scheduler classes></android.view.View__scheduler classes><android.view.View__ (></android.view.View__ (><android.view.View__code></android.view.View__code><android.view.View__), of which the ></android.view.View__), of which the ><android.view.View__CFS class></android.view.View__CFS class><android.view.View__ is the highest-priority one. Another one is the ></android.view.View__ is the highest-priority one. Another one is the ><android.view.View__real-time></android.view.View__real-time><android.view.View__ scheduler class, tailored as the name suggests for tasks that need responsiveness.></android.view.View__ scheduler class, tailored as the name suggests for tasks that need responsiveness.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Interactive tasks would run for small amounts of time but need to run quickly as events happen. CPU-intensive tasks don’t require to complete ASAP but require longer CPU time. Based on that, time accounting is what guarantees fairness in the Linux CFS scheduler as long as the task that runs for less time will run next.></android.view.View__Interactive tasks would run for small amounts of time but need to run quickly as events happen. CPU-intensive tasks don’t require to complete ASAP but require longer CPU time. Based on that, time accounting is what guarantees fairness in the Linux CFS scheduler as long as the task that runs for less time will run next.><android.view.View__This comes to the time accounting, so let’s start to dig into it!></android.view.View__This comes to the time accounting, so let’s start to dig into it!><android.view.View__2. Time accounting></android.view.View__2. Time accounting><android.view.View__Linux CFS actually does not directly assign timeslices to tasks as the O(1) scheduler did, instead it measures execution time, in order to be flexible with respect to both interactive and processor-intensive tasks.></android.view.View__Linux CFS actually does not directly assign timeslices to tasks as the O(1) scheduler did, instead it measures execution time, in order to be flexible with respect to both interactive and processor-intensive tasks.><android.view.View__The runtime></android.view.View__The runtime><android.view.View__Remember, the fundamental rule in the Completely Fair Scheduler is: the task that ran less, will run next! Which is, each task should have its fair slice of processor time when it needs! For example, interactive tasks can run frequently but for less time than intensive ones, and still have their fair amount of CPU time.></android.view.View__Remember, the fundamental rule in the Completely Fair Scheduler is: the task that ran less, will run next! Which is, each task should have its fair slice of processor time when it needs! For example, interactive tasks can run frequently but for less time than intensive ones, and still have their fair amount of CPU time.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The implementation is written in the></android.view.View__The implementation is written in the><android.view.View__update_curr()></android.view.View__update_curr()><android.view.View__ function, which is called periodically to account tasks for the CPU time they used in the last period (></android.view.View__ function, which is called periodically to account tasks for the CPU time they used in the last period (><android.view.View__delta_exec></android.view.View__delta_exec><android.view.View__).></android.view.View__).></android.view.View__><android.view.View__The virtual runtime></android.view.View__The virtual runtime><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The execution time is ></android.view.View__The execution time is ><android.view.View__further weighted></android.view.View__further weighted><android.view.View__ to implement priority between tasks. This is done by the ></android.view.View__ to implement priority between tasks. This is done by the ><android.view.View__fair delta calculation></android.view.View__fair delta calculation><android.view.View__. The more the weight, the more time the task will have.></android.view.View__. The more the weight, the more time the task will have.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Example></android.view.View__Example><android.view.View__Let' do an example with timeslices: considering a single CPU, if every T time period two tasks A and B run respectively with a weight of 1 and 2, the allocated CPU time is obtained by multiplying T by the ratio of the weight to the sum of the weights of all running tasks:></android.view.View__Let' do an example with timeslices: considering a single CPU, if every T time period two tasks A and B run respectively with a weight of 1 and 2, the allocated CPU time is obtained by multiplying T by the ratio of the weight to the sum of the weights of all running tasks:><android.view.View__CPU_timeslice(A) = T * (1 / (1 + 2))).
CPU_timeslice(B) = T * (2 / (1 + 2))).
></android.view.View__CPU_timeslice(A) = T * (1 / (1 + 2))).
CPU_timeslice(B) = T * (2 / (1 + 2))).
><android.view.View__For each T time period, task A will run for 0.334~T and task B 0.667~T.></android.view.View__For each T time period, task A will run for 0.334~T and task B 0.667~T.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__This is what is calculated ></android.view.View__This is what is calculated ><android.view.View__here></android.view.View__here><android.view.View__.></android.view.View__.></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Implementation></android.view.View__Implementation><android.view.View__Coming to the actual implementation, the CFS class accounts tasks for their real execution time considering their weight, which is ensured by periodically measuring the runtime and multiplying it by the ratio weight/(base weight).></android.view.View__Coming to the actual implementation, the CFS class accounts tasks for their real execution time considering their weight, which is ensured by periodically measuring the runtime and multiplying it by the ratio weight/(base weight).><android.view.View__runtime += runtime * (w / base w)).
></android.view.View__runtime += runtime * (w / base w)).
><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Which is exactly what is done in ></android.view.View__Which is exactly what is done in ><android.view.View__update_curr()></android.view.View__update_curr()><android.view.View__:></android.view.View__:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__static void update_curr(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
{
	struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
	...
	delta_exec = now - curr->exec_start;
	...
	curr->vruntime += calc_delta_fair(delta_exec, curr);
	...
}
></android.view.View__static void update_curr(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
{
	struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
	...
	delta_exec = now - curr->exec_start;
	...
	curr->vruntime += calc_delta_fair(delta_exec, curr);
	...

The bigger the depth of the hierarchy, the more the weight gets diluted. Adding a heavily weighted task to one child group is not going to afflict the overall tasks tree the same as it would do if it was part of the root group. This is because the task weight is relative to the group which the task is put into.></android.view.View__For the sake of simplicity let’s remember this: the groups are hierarchical, and a task is part of a task group. updated><android.view.View__ (scaled) in></android.view.View__ (scaled) in><android.view.View__entity_tick()></android.view.View__entity_tick()><android.view.View__ based on how much the task group is loaded on the local CPU.></android.view.View__ based on how much the task group is loaded on the local CPU.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The weight is multiplied by the ratio of the ></android.view.View__The weight is multiplied by the ratio of the ><android.view.View__load></android.view.View__load><android.view.View__ of the task group running on the local CPU (which is the task group’s runqueue) to the global load of the task group.></android.view.View__ of the task group running on the local CPU (which is the task group’s runqueue) to the global load of done><android.view.View__ if configured Linux for symmetrical multiprocessor, otherwise the></android.view.View__ if configured Linux for symmetrical multiprocessor, otherwise the><android.view.View__shares></android.view.View__shares><android.view.View__is not scaled></android.view.View__is not scaled><android.view.View__.></android.view.View__.></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__In detail, the load is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group or the task group’s runqueue.></android.view.View__In detail, the load is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group or the task group’s runqueue.><android.view.View__shares = shares * (runqueue's load / task group's load)
></android.view.View__shares = shares * (runqueue's load / task group's load)
><android.view.View__TL;DR: the ratio is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the runqueues to the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group:></android.view.View__TL;DR: the ratio is the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the runqueues to the sum of the weights of the entities that compose the task group:><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The calculcation is done by the></android.view.View__The calculcation is done by the><android.view.View__calc_group_shares()></android.view.View__calc_group_shares()><android.view.View__ function, to get the final value of the task group’s shares that will weight the virtual runtime of the task group schedule entity:></android.view.View__ function, to get the final value of the task group’s shares that will weight the virtual runtime of the task group schedule entity:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__static long calc_group_shares(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
{
	long tg_weight, tg_shares, load, shares;
	/
	struct task_group *tg = cfs_rq->tg;

	/*
	   tg_shares is the task group's CPU shares.
	 */
	tg_shares = READ_ONCE(tg->shares);

	/*
	   load is the load of the local CFS runqueue which is,
	   the load of the task group on the local CPU.
	 */
	load = max(scale_load_down(cfs_rq->load.weight), cfs_rq->avg.load_avg);

	/*
	   tg_weight is the global load of the task group.
	 */
	tg_weight = atomic_long_read(&tg->load_avg);

	/* Ensure tg_weight >= load */
	tg_weight -= cfs_rq->tg_load_avg_contrib;
	tg_weight += load;

	shares = (tg_shares * load);
	if (tg_weight)
		shares /= tg_weight;

	// ...

	/*
	   shares is now the per CPU-scaled task group shares.
	*/
	return clamp_t(long, shares, MIN_SHARES, tg_shares);
}
></android.view.View__static long calc_group_shares(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
{
	long tg_weight, tg_shares, load, shares;
	/
	struct task_group *tg = cfs_rq->tg;

	/*
	   tg_shares is the task group's CPU shares.
	 */
	tg_shares = READ_ONCE(tg->shares);

	/*
	   load is the load of the local CFS runqueue which is,
	   the load of the task group on the local CPU.
	 */
	load = max(scale_load_down(cfs_rq->load.weight), cfs_rq->avg.load_avg);

	/*
	   tg_weight is the global load of the task group.
	 */
	tg_weight = atomic_long_read(&tg->load_avg);

	/* Ensure tg_weight >= load */
	tg_weight -= cfs_rq->tg_load_avg_contrib;
	tg_weight += load;

	shares = (tg_shares * load);
	if (tg_weight)
		shares /= tg_weight;

	// ...

	/*
	   shares is now the per CPU-scaled task group shares.
	*/
	return clamp_t(long, shares, MIN_SHARES, tg_shares);
}

		shares /= tg_weight;

 * Called by the timer interrupt handler every 1/HZ seconds.
 */
scheduler_tick()
/* The local CPU */
-> int cpu = smp_processor_id();
/* The local CPU runqueue */
-> struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
/* The local CPU runqueue currently running task */
-> struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
/* The current running task's scheduler class' periodic tick function. */
-> curr->sched_class->task_tick(rq, curr)
   /* Let's assume the class is CFS. */
   -> task_tick_fair()
      -> struct sched_entity *se = &curr->se;
      /*
       * For each schedule entity through parent task groups
       * up to the root task group.
       */
      -> for_each_sched_entity(se)
         /* The runqueue where the entity is placed. */
         -> cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
         -> entity_tick(cfs_rq, se)
            /*
             * Update the virtual runtime for the current running entity
             * on the current selected by loop-task group's runqueue.
             */
            -> update_curr(cfs_rq)
               -> struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
               -> delta_exec = now - curr->exec_start;
               -> curr->exec_start = now;
               -> curr->vruntime += calc_delta_fair(delta_exec, curr);
            /*
             * If it's a task group update the shares 
             * based on its group runqueue,
             * which is the group load on the local CPU
             */
            -> update_cfs_group(se)
               /* The CFS runqueue of the entity, if it's a task group. */
               -> struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
               /* If the entity is a task, skip */
               -> if (!gcfs_rq)
               ->   return;
               /*
                * Update the CPU shares for the task group entity.
                */
               -> shares = calc_group_shares(gcfs_rq);
               -> reweight_entity(cfs_rq_of(se), se, shares);
></android.view.View__/*
 * Called by the timer interrupt handler every 1/HZ seconds.
 */
scheduler_tick()
/* The local CPU */
-> int cpu = smp_processor_id();
/* The local CPU runqueue */
-> struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
/* The local CPU runqueue currently running task */
-> struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
/* The current running task's scheduler class' periodic tick function. */
-> curr->sched_class->task_tick(rq, curr)
   /* Let's assume the class is CFS. */
   -> task_tick_fair()
      -> struct sched_entity *se = &curr->se;
      /*
       * For each schedule entity through parent task groups
       * up to the root task group.
       */
      -> for_each_sched_entity(se)
         /* The runqueue where the entity is placed. */
         -> cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
         -> entity_tick(cfs_rq, se)
            /*
             * Update the virtual runtime for the current running entity
             * on the current selected by loop-task group's runqueue.
             */
            -> update_curr(cfs_rq)
               -> struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
               -> delta_exec = now - curr->exec_start;
               -> curr->exec_start = now;
               -> curr->vruntime += calc_delta_fair(delta_exec, curr);
            /*
             * If it's a task group update the shares 
             * based on its group runqueue,
             * which is the group load on the local CPU
             */
            -> update_cfs_group(se)
               /* The CFS runqueue of the entity, if it's a task group. */
               -> struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
               /* If the entity is a task, skip */
               -> if (!gcfs_rq)
               ->   return;
               /*
                * Update the CPU shares for the task group entity.
                */
               -> shares = calc_group_shares(gcfs_rq);
               -> reweight_entity(cfs_rq_of(se), se, shares);

add_wait_queue(q, &wait);

while (!condition) { /* condition is the event that we are waiting for */ 
	prepare_to_wait(&q, &wait, TASK_INTERRUPTIBLE);
	if (signal_pending(current))
 		/* handle signal */
	schedule(); 
}
finish_wait(&q, &wait);

This is the fourth release of , and as you might guess from the version number, it's based on the current Long Term Support release of Ubuntu, version 22.04. Ubuntu Core is quite a different product from normal Ubuntu, even the text-only Ubuntu Server. Core has no conventional package manager, just Snap, and the OS itself is built from Snap packages. Snap installations and updates are transactional: this means that either they succeed completely, or the OS automatically rolls them back, leaving no trace except an entry in a log file.', ix=''}, comp{id=166, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Ubuntu releases Core 22: Its IoT and edge distro A tougher nut to crack than the regular flavor, some will find it very tasty', ix=''}, comp{id=167, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=168, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Liam Proven in Prague', ix=''}, comp{id=169, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Fri 17 Jun 2022 ', ix=''}, comp{id=170, n='android.view.View', t='', d='// ', ix=''}, comp{id=171, n='android.view.View', t='', d='07:33 UTC', ix=''}, comp{id=172, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' ', ix=''}, comp{id=173, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Canonical's Linux distro for edge devices and the Internet of Things, Ubuntu Core 22, is out.', ix=''}, comp{id=174, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=175, n='android.view.View', t='', d='This is the fourth release of ', ix=''}, comp{id=176, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Ubuntu Core', ix=''}, comp{id=177, n='android.view.View', t='', d=', and as you might guess from the version number, it's based on the current Long Term Support release of Ubuntu, version 22.04.', ix=''}, comp{id=178, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Ubuntu Core is quite a different product from normal Ubuntu, even the text-only Ubuntu Server. The flaw is tracked as , an elevation-of-privilege vulnerability in Microsoft's Service Fabric. An attacker would need read/write access to the cluster as well as the ability to execute code within a Linux container granted access to the Service Fabric runtime in order to wreak havoc. comp{id=229, n='android.widget.ListView', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=230, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Wed 29 Jun 2022 // 11:39 UTC  is a rolling-release Linux distro based on . Although the project is relatively new, having started in 2019, it's the successor to an earlier Arch-based distro called Antergos, so it's not quite as immature as its youth might imply. It's a little more vanilla than Antergos was – for instance, it uses the Calamares cross-distro installer. EndeavourOS hews more closely to its parent distro than, for example, Manjaro, which we . Unlike Manjaro, it doesn't have its own staging repositories or releases. It installs packages directly from the upstream Arch repositories, using the standard Arch package manager pacman. It also bundles  to easily fetch packages from the Arch User Repository, . The yay command takes the same switches as pacman does, so if you wanted to install, say, Google Chrome, it's as simple as yay -s google-chrome and a few seconds later, it's done.', ix=''}, comp{id=231, n='android.view.View', t='', d='EndeavourOS Artemis: Arch Linux, but a bit friendlier The Reg FOSS desk takes the latest release, 22.6, for a spin', ix=''}, comp{id=232, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=233, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Liam Proven in Prague', ix=''}, comp{id=234, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Wed 29 Jun 2022 ', ix=''}, comp{id=235, n='android.view.View', t='', d='// ', ix=''}, comp{id=236, n='android.view.View', t='', d='11:39 UTC', ix=''}, comp{id=237, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' ', ix=''}, comp{id=238, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=239, n='android.view.View', t='', d='EndeavourOS', ix=''}, comp{id=240, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' is a rolling-release Linux distro based on ', ix=''}, comp{id=241, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Arch Linux', ix=''}, comp{id=242, n='android.view.View', t='', d='. The goal is to "drastically" improve the performance of Vim scripts, while also bringing the scripting language more into line with widely used languages such as JavaScript, TypeScript, and Java. The existing scripting language, Vimscript, remains and will still work. Only scripts beginning with the linevim9script will be handled differently. The syntax changes are relatively modest; the important differences are in things like local versus global variables and functions, and that functions defined with :def will be compiled before they are run. This allows many errors to be caught in advance, but more significantly, compiled functions execute from 10× to 1000× faster.', ix=''}, comp{id=278, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Old-school editor Vim hits version 9 with faster scripting language All of the famed user-friendliness and ease of use – and 'drastically' better performance', ix=''}, comp{id=279, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=280, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Liam Proven in Prague', ix=''}, comp{id=281, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Thu 30 Jun 2022 ', ix=''}, comp{id=282, n='android.view.View', t='', d='// ', ix=''}, comp{id=283, n='android.view.View', t='', d='14:59 UTC', ix=''}, comp{id=284, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' ', ix=''}, comp{id=285, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Old-school editor fans, rejoice: some two and a half years after version 8.2, Vim 9 is here, and with a much faster scripting language.', ix=''}, comp{id=286, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=287, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Vim 9', ix=''}, comp{id=288, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' has only a single big new feature: a new scripting language, ', ix=''}, comp{id=289, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Vim9script', ix=''}, comp{id=290, n='android.view.View', t='', d='. The Unity remix is progressively replacing GNOME components, such as the text editor and file manager, with ones from other desktop projects, in order to get back features which GNOME has removed – notably, menu bars.><android.view.View__So Ubuntu Unity 22.04 uses the Nemo file manager from the Cinnamon desktop, rather than GNOME's Nautilus, and MATE's Pluma text editor instead of GEdit. The GNOME Shell is still installed, although it doesn't appear on the login menu. The remix uses the GNOME system monitor, which has no menu bar – possibly because the MATE one works fine, but doesn't show up in the app launcher. In the volume control, scrolling down increases the volume, and up decreases it, the opposite of what we expected. And on the accessibility front, several apps' menu bars don't respond to keyboard controls, including the terminal.></android.view.View__The remix still has a few small rough edges. The GNOME Shell is still installed, although it doesn't appear on the login menu. The remix uses the GNOME system monitor, which has no menu bar – possibly because the MATE one works fine, but doesn't show up in the app launcher. In the volume control, scrolling down increases the volume, and up decreases it, the opposite of what we expected. like><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__Sun 3 Jul 2022 // 09:33 UTC China’s efforts to end its reliance on Microsoft Windows got a boost with the launch of the openKylin project. The  aims to accelerate development of the country’s home-grown Kylin Linux distro by opening the project up to a broader community of developers, colleges, and universities to contribute code. Launched in 2001, Kylin was based on a FreeBSD kernel and was intended for use in government and military offices, where Chinese authorities have repeatedly attempted to eliminate foreign operating systems.><android.view.View__China rallies support for Kylin Linux in war on Windows openKylin project is latest chapter in Beijing's love-hate relationship with Redmond></android.view.View__China Launched in 2001, Kylin was based on a FreeBSD kernel and was intended for use in government and military offices, where Chinese authorities have repeatedly attempted to eliminate foreign operating systems.><android.view.View__Thu 23 Jun 2022 // 17:46 UTC The UBPorts community is in the final stages of preparing its next release and it's calling for testers. OTA-23 is getting close – the project's Github looks quite good to us – and if you're lucky enough to have one of the project's supported devices lying around, then you can . Many of them are a few years old now, so there's a good chance that you've already replaced them and they sit unloved and neglected in a drawer. The starred entries in the list of  are the best supported and should have no show-stopping problems. In order of seniority, that means: the LG-made Google Nexus 5 (2013); the original Oneplus One (2014); two models of Sony Xperia X, the F5121 and F5122 (2016); and Google's Pixel 3a and 3a XL (2019).><android.view.View__Ubuntu Touch OTA-23 is coming: Do you have one of the older model phones that can test it? OTA-23 is getting close – the project's Github looks quite good to us – and if you're lucky enough to have one of the project's supported devices lying around, then you can . Many of them are a few years old now, so there's a good chance that you've already replaced them and they sit unloved and neglected in a drawer. The starred entries in the list of  are the best supported and should have no show-stopping problems. In order of seniority, that means: the LG-made Google Nexus 5 (2013); the original Oneplus One (2014); two models of Sony Xperia X, the F5121 and F5122 (2016); and Google's Pixel 3a and 3a XL (2019).><android.view.View__Fri 17 Jun 2022 // 07:33 UTC Canonical's Linux distro for edge devices and the Internet of Things, Ubuntu Core 22, is out. This is the fourth release of , and as you might guess from the version number, it's based on the current Long Term Support release of Ubuntu, version 22.04. Ubuntu Core is quite a different product from normal Ubuntu, even the text-only Ubuntu Server. Core has no conventional package manager, just Snap, and the OS itself is built from Snap packages. Snap installations and updates are transactional: this means that either they succeed completely, or the OS automatically rolls them back, leaving no trace except an entry in a log file.><android.view.View__Ubuntu releases Core 22: Its IoT and edge distro A tougher nut to crack than the regular flavor, some will find it very tasty></android.view.View__Ubuntu releases Core 22: Its IoT and edge distro A tougher nut to crack than the regular flavor, some will find it very tasty><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague></android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague><android.view.View__Fri 17 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Fri 17 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__07:33 UTC></android.view.View__07:33 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Canonical's Linux distro for edge devices and the Internet of Things, Ubuntu Core 22, is out.></android.view.View__Canonical's Linux distro for edge devices and the Internet of Things, Ubuntu Core 22, is out.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__This is the fourth release of ></android.view.View__This is the fourth release of ><android.view.View__Ubuntu Core></android.view.View__Ubuntu Core><android.view.View__, and as you might guess from the version number, it's based on the current Long Term Support release of Ubuntu, version 22.04.></android.view.View__, and as you might guess from the version number, it's based on the current Long Term Support release of Ubuntu, version 22.04.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Ubuntu Core is quite a different product from normal Ubuntu, even the text-only Ubuntu Server. This is the fourth release of , and as you might guess from the version number, it's based on the current Long Term Support release of Ubuntu, version 22.04. Ubuntu Core is quite a different product from normal Ubuntu, even the text-only Ubuntu Server. Core has no conventional package manager, just Snap, and the OS itself is built from Snap packages. Snap installations and updates are transactional: this means that either they succeed completely, or the OS automatically rolls them back, leaving no trace except an entry in a log file.></android.widget.ListView__><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__Sat 2 Jul 2022 // 10:07 UTC Interview In June, Purism began shipping a privacy-focused smartphone called Librem 5 USA that runs on a version of Linux called PureOS rather than Android or iOS. As the name suggests, it's made in America – all the electronics are assembled in its Carlsbad, California facility, using as many US-fabricated parts as possible. While past privacy-focused phones, such as 's Android-based Blackphone failed to win much market share, the political situation is different now than it was seven years ago. Supply-chain provenance has become more important in recent years, thanks to concerns about the national security implications of foreign-made tech gear. The  comes at a cost, starting at $1,999, though there are now US government agencies willing to pay that price for homegrown hardware they can trust – and evidently tech enthusiasts, too.><android.view.View__The App Gap and supply chains: Purism CEO on what's ahead for the Librem 5 USA Freedoms eroded, iOS-Android duopoly under fire, chip sources questioned – it's all an opportunity for this phone></android.view.View__The App Gap and supply chains: Purism CEO on what's ahead for the Librem 5 USA Freedoms eroded, iOS-Android duopoly under fire, chip sources questioned – it's all an opportunity for this phone><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Thomas Claburn in San Francisco></android.view.View__Thomas Claburn in San Francisco><android.view.View__Sat 2 Jul 2022 ></android.view.View__Sat 2 Jul 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__10:07 UTC></android.view.View__10:07 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Interview In June, Purism began shipping a privacy-focused smartphone called Librem 5 USA that runs on a version of Linux called PureOS rather than Android or iOS. As the name suggests, it's made in America – all the electronics are assembled in its Carlsbad, California facility, using as many US-fabricated parts as possible. The  comes at a cost, starting at $1,999, though there are now US government agencies willing to pay that price for homegrown hardware they can trust – and evidently tech enthusiasts, too.><android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 // 13:40 UTC Microsoft is flagging up a security hole in its Service Fabric technology when using containerized Linux workloads, and urged customers to upgrade their clusters to the most recent release. The flaw is tracked as , an elevation-of-privilege vulnerability in Microsoft's Service Fabric. An attacker would need read/write access to the cluster as well as the ability to execute code within a Linux container granted access to the Service Fabric runtime in order to wreak havoc. Through a compromised container, for instance, a miscreant could gain control of the resource's host Service Fabric node and potentially the entire cluster.><android.view.View__FabricScape: Microsoft warns of vuln in Service Fabric Not trying to spin this as a Linux security hole, surely?></android.view.View__FabricScape: Microsoft warns of vuln in Service Fabric Not trying to spin this as a Linux security hole, surely?><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Richard Speed></android.view.View__Richard Speed><android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__13:40 UTC></android.view.View__13:40 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Microsoft is flagging up a security hole in its Service Fabric technology when using containerized Linux workloads, and urged customers to upgrade their clusters to the most recent release.></android.view.View__Microsoft is flagging up a security hole in its Service Fabric technology when using containerized Linux workloads, and urged customers to upgrade their clusters to the most recent release.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__The flaw is tracked as ></android.view.View__The flaw is tracked as ><android.view.View__CVE-2022-30137></android.view.View__CVE-2022-30137><android.view.View__, an elevation-of-privilege vulnerability in Microsoft's Service Fabric. At least since last December, when  added support for Rust as a second language for kernel code, the Linux community has been anticipating this transition, in the hope it leads to greater stability and security. In a conversation with Dirk Hohndel, chief open source officer at Cardano, Torvalds said the patches to integrate Rust have not yet been merged because there's far more caution among Linux kernel maintainers than there was 30 years ago.><android.view.View__Linus Torvalds says Rust is coming to the Linux kernel 'real soon now' Maintainer lack of familiarity won't be an issue, chief insists, citing his own bafflement when faced with Perl></android.view.View__Linus Torvalds says Rust is coming to the Linux kernel 'real soon now' Maintainer lack of familiarity won't be an issue, chief Although the project is relatively new, having started in 2019, it's the successor to an earlier Arch-based distro called Antergos, so it's not quite as immature as its youth might imply. It's a little more vanilla than Antergos was – for instance, it uses the Calamares cross-distro installer. EndeavourOS hews more closely to its parent distro than, for example, Manjaro, which we . Unlike Manjaro, it doesn't have its own staging repositories or releases. It installs packages directly from the upstream Arch repositories, using the standard Arch package manager pacman. It also bundles  to easily fetch packages from the Arch User Repository, . The yay command takes the same switches as pacman does, so if you wanted to install, say, Google Chrome, it's as simple as yay -s google-chrome and a few seconds later, it's done.><android.view.View__EndeavourOS Artemis: Arch Linux, but a bit friendlier The Reg FOSS desk takes the latest release, 22.6, for a spin></android.view.View__EndeavourOS Artemis: Arch Linux, but a bit friendlier The Reg FOSS desk takes the latest release, 22.6, for a spin><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague></android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague><android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Wed 29 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__11:39 UTC></android.view.View__11:39 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__EndeavourOS></android.view.View__EndeavourOS><android.view.View__ is a rolling-release Linux distro based on ></android.view.View__ is a rolling-release Linux distro based on ><android.view.View__Arch Linux></android.view.View__Arch Linux><android.view.View__. It's a little more vanilla than Antergos was – for instance, it uses the Calamares cross-distro installer. EndeavourOS hews more closely to its parent distro than, for example, Manjaro, which we . Unlike Manjaro, it doesn't have its own staging repositories or releases. It installs packages directly from the upstream Arch repositories, using the standard Arch package manager pacman. It also bundles  to easily fetch packages from the Arch User Repository, . Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 distributions are now supported on Windows Server 2022. The  in preview form last month and represented somewhat of an about-face from the Windows giant, whose employees had previously complained that while the tech was handy for desktop users, sticking it on a server might mean it gets used for things for which it wasn't intended. Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 distributions are now supported on Windows Server 2022. The  in preview form last month and represented somewhat of an about-face from the Windows giant, whose employees had previously complained that while the tech was handy for desktop users, sticking it on a server might mean it gets used for things for which it wasn't intended. (And Windows Server absolutely had to have the bloated user interface of its desktop stablemate as well, right?)><android.view.View__Thu 30 Jun 2022 // 14:59 UTC Old-school editor fans, rejoice: some two and a half years after version 8.2, Vim 9 is here, and with a much faster scripting language.  has only a single big new feature: a new scripting language, . The goal is to "drastically" improve the performance of Vim scripts, while also bringing the scripting language more into line with widely used languages such as JavaScript, TypeScript, and Java. The existing scripting language, Vimscript, remains and will still work. Only scripts beginning with the linevim9script will be handled differently. The syntax changes are relatively modest; the important differences are in things like local versus global variables and functions, and that functions defined with :def will be compiled before they are run. This allows many errors to be caught in advance, but more significantly, compiled functions execute from 10× to 1000× faster.><android.view.View__Old-school editor Vim hits version 9 with faster scripting language All of the famed user-friendliness and ease of use – and 'drastically' better performance></android.view.View__Old-school editor Vim hits version 9 with faster scripting language All of the famed user-friendliness and ease of use – and 'drastically' better performance><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague></android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague><android.view.View__Thu 30 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Thu 30 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__14:59 UTC></android.view.View__14:59 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Old-school editor fans, rejoice: some two and a half years after version 8.2, Vim 9 is here, and with a much faster scripting language.></android.view.View__Old-school editor fans, rejoice: some two and a half years after version 8.2, Vim 9 is here, and with a much faster scripting language.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Vim 9></android.view.View__Vim 9><android.view.View__ has only a single big new feature: a new scripting language, ></android.view.View__ has only a single big new feature: a new scripting language, ><android.view.View__Vim9script></android.view.View__Vim9script><android.view.View__. Only scripts beginning with the linevim9script will be handled differently. The syntax changes are relatively modest; the important differences are in things like local versus global variables and functions, and that functions defined with :def will be compiled before they are run. This allows many errors to be caught in advance, but more significantly, compiled functions execute from 10× to 1000× faster.><android.view.View__CONTINUE READING></android.view.View__CONTINUE READING></android.view.View__Thu 30 Jun 2022 // 14:59 UTC Old-school editor fans, rejoice: some two and a half years after version 8.2, Vim 9 is here, and with a much faster scripting language.  has only a single big new feature: a new scripting language, . The goal is to "drastically" improve the performance of Vim scripts, while also bringing the scripting language more into line with widely used languages such as JavaScript, TypeScript, and Java. The existing scripting language, Vimscript, remains and will still work. Only scripts beginning with the linevim9script will be handled differently. The syntax changes are relatively modest; the important differences are in things like local versus global variables and functions, and that functions defined with :def will be compiled before they are run. This allows many errors to be caught in advance, but more significantly, compiled functions execute from 10× to 1000× faster.><android.view.View__Wed 22 Jun 2022 // 08:30 UTC Version 21.3 of Manjaro - codenamed "Ruah" - is here, with kernel 5.15, but don't let its beginner-friendly billing fool you: you will need a clue with this one. Manjaro Linux is one of the more popular Arch Linux derivatives, and the new  is the latest update to version 21, released in 2021. There are three official variants, with GNOME 42.2, KDE 5.24.5 or Xfce 4.16 desktops, plus community builds with Budgie, Cinnamon, MATE, a choice of tiling window managers (i3 or Sway), plus a Docker image. The Reg took its  a few months ago. Arch is one of the older rolling-release distros, and it's also famously rather minimal. The installation process isn't trivial: it's driven from the command line, and the user does a lot of the hard work, manually partitioning disks and so on.><android.view.View__Leading Arch Linux derivative Manjaro puts out version 21.3 A simpler, easier remix sounds like a good thing, but glitches like these shouldn't be in a point release></android.view.View__Leading Arch Linux derivative Manjaro puts out version 21.3 A simpler, easier remix sounds like a good thing, but glitches like these shouldn't be in a point release><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague></android.view.View__Liam Proven in Prague><android.view.View__Wed 22 Jun 2022 ></android.view.View__Wed 22 Jun 2022 ><android.view.View__// ></android.view.View__// ><android.view.View__08:30 UTC></android.view.View__08:30 UTC><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Version 21.3 of Manjaro - codenamed "Ruah" - is here, with kernel 5.15, but don't let its beginner-friendly billing fool you: you will need a clue with this one.></android.view.View__Version 21.3 of Manjaro - codenamed "Ruah" - is here, with kernel 5.15, but don't let its beginner-friendly billing fool you: you will need a clue with this one.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Manjaro Linux is one of the more popular Arch Linux derivatives, and the new ></android.view.View__Manjaro Linux is one of the more popular Arch Linux derivatives, and the new ><android.view.View__version 21.3></android.view.View__version 21.3><android.view.View__ is the latest update to version 21, released in 2021.
