details></android.view.View__></android.widget.ListView__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Description></android.view.View__Description><android.view.View__Product Description></android.view.View__Product Description><android.view.View__Linux Kernel Development details the design and implementation of the Linux kernel, presenting the content in a manner that is beneficial to those writing and developing kernel code, as well as to programmers seeking to better understand the operating system and become more efficient and productive in their coding.></android.view.View__Linux Kernel Development details the design and implementation of the Linux kernel, presenting the content in a manner that is beneficial to those writing and developing kernel code, as well as to programmers seeking to better understand the operating system and become more efficient and productive in their coding.><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ><android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.></android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ><android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.></android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ><android.view.View__The third edition of Linux Kernel Development includes new and updated material throughout the Cover></android.view.View__From the Back Cover><android.view.View__Linux Kernel Development details the design and implementation of the Linux kernel, presenting the content in a manner that is beneficial to those writing and developing kernel code, as well as to programmers seeking to better understand the operating system and become more efficient and productive in their coding.></android.view.View__Linux Kernel Development details the design and implementation of the Linux kernel, presenting the content in a manner that is beneficial to those writing and developing kernel code, as well as to programmers seeking to better understand the operating system and become more efficient and productive in their coding.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.></android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.></android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__The third edition of Linux Kernel Development includes new and updated material throughout the Author></android.view.View__About the Author><android.view.View__Robert Love is an open source programmer, speaker, and author who has been using and contributing to Linux for more than 15 years. He is currently senior software engineer at Google, where he was a member of the team that developed the Android mobile platform’s kernel. Prior to Google, he was Chief Architect, Linux Desktop, at Novell. Before Novell, he was a kernel engineer at MontaVista Software and Ximian.></android.view.View__Robert Love is an open source programmer, speaker, and author who has been using and contributing to Linux for more than 15 years. He is currently senior software engineer at Google, where he was a member of the team that developed the Android mobile platform’s kernel. Prior to Google, he was Chief Architect, Linux Desktop, at Novell. Before Novell, he was a kernel engineer at MontaVista Software and Ximian.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__Love’s kernel projects include the preemptive kernel, the process scheduler, the kernel events layer, inotify,VM enhancements, and several device drivers.></android.view.View__Love’s kernel projects include the preemptive kernel, the process scheduler, the kernel events layer, inotify,VM enhancements, and several device drivers.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__He has given numerous talks on and has written multiple articles about the Linux kernel and is a contributing editor for Linux Journal. His other books include Linux System Programming and Linux in a Nutshell.></android.view.View__He has given numerous talks on and has written multiple articles about the Linux kernel and is a contributing editor for Linux Journal. Most RSS apps assume that all posts have a title, even though titles are technically optional in the spec. But I think this is an important distinction because if you think about Twitter-like posting, it should be fast and convenient; making up a title first interrupts the flow of posting.></android.view.View__Not having an RSS item title might take some getting used to for mainstream blogging clients and readers. Most RSS apps assume that all posts have a title, even though titles are technically optional in the spec. But I think this is an important distinction because if you think about Twitter-like posting, it should be fast and convenient; making up a title first interrupts the flow of posting.><android.view.View__The specific rule for post length or which feeds you include can be useful. centralized platforms create problems for society. By posting to your own site, you control your content, distributing it more evenly across the web and minimizing the power of big tech companies.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__Massive centralized platforms create problems for society. By posting to your own site, you control your content, distributing it more evenly across the web and minimizing the power of big tech companies.></android.view.View__Massive centralized platforms create problems for society. By posting to your own site, you control your content, distributing it more evenly across the web and minimizing the power of big tech companies.></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__This might seem like too much work for most people. With many of today’s blogging tools, it is. We must work simultaneously on open standards and on making software that follows those standards as easy to use as possible for everyone.></android.view.View__This might seem like too much work for most people. With many of today’s blogging tools, it is. We must work simultaneously on open standards and on making software that follows those standards as easy to use as possible for everyone.><android.view.View__What we don’t want to do is reinvent the wheel with a new social media-like protocol that isn’t rooted in the web and blogs. Others have tried to come up with new systems for microblogging that don’t use blogs. But the word “blog” is part of “microblog” for a reason. They differ only in length. By using blogs, we get to keep everything that is valuable about blogging. We get to keep existing blog software and IndieWeb-friendly formats.></android.view.View__What we don’t want to do is reinvent the wheel with a new social media-like protocol that isn’t rooted in the web and blogs. Others have tried to come up with new systems for microblogging that don’t use blogs. But the word “blog” is part of “microblog” for a reason. They differ only in length. By using blogs, we get to keep everything that is valuable about blogging. We get to keep existing blog software and IndieWeb-friendly formats.><android.view.View__Blogs are web sites with reverse-chronological posts written by people. The newest posts are always at the top of the web site. They can be news sites, corporate sites, travel sites, photo sites, tech sites. They are often personal, with an individual’s voice. Readers want to keep visiting a blog because there’s a story, unfolding with each post. The passing of time is a fundamental element to what defines a blog.></android.view.View__Blogs are web sites with reverse-chronological posts written by people. The newest posts are always at the top of the web site. They can be news sites, corporate sites, travel sites, photo sites, tech sites. They are often personal, with an individual’s voice. Readers want to keep visiting a blog because there’s a story, unfolding with each post. The passing of time is a fundamental element to what defines a blog.><android.view.View__This emphasis on time is even more obvious for microblogs. Microblogs are blogs with very short posts. Because short posts are easy to write, there are usually more of them. In the case of a microblogging service like Twitter or Micro.blog, friends' posts are combined together in a timeline.></android.view.View__This emphasis on time is even more obvious for microblogs. Microblogs are blogs with very short posts. Because short posts are easy to write, there are usually more of them. In the case of a microblogging service like Twitter or Micro.blog, friends' posts are combined together in a timeline.><android.view.View__In an open platform based on indie microblogs, posts in the timeline come from blogs at the author’s own domain name. This helps distribute content across the web and bypasses the bottleneck of posting only through big social networks, reducing their influence:></android.view.View__In an open platform based on indie microblogs, posts in the timeline come from blogs at the author’s own domain name. This helps distribute content across the web and bypasses the bottleneck of posting only through big social networks, reducing their influence:><android.view.View__Recent posts are placed at the top of the timeline. Older posts fall to the bottom, and eventually drop off. With this focus on the new, some people consider microblogging ephemeral, but it doesn’t have to be.></android.view.View__Recent posts are placed at the top of the timeline. Older posts fall to the bottom, and eventually drop off. With this focus on the new, some people consider microblogging ephemeral, but it doesn’t have to be.><android.view.View__Indie microblogging is about taking ownership of our microblog post content. It’s about reclaiming the definition of what a microblog is from Twitter. Microblogs and social networks are big components of the web — too important to be contained in such a small number of closed, centralized platforms.></android.view.View__Indie microblogging is about taking ownership of our microblog post content. It’s about reclaiming the definition of what a microblog is from Twitter. Microblogs and social networks are big components of the web — too important to be contained in such a small number of closed, centralized platforms.><android.view.View__An indie microblog is a blog that contains short posts at your own domain name. It can be hosted by multiple providers, but it is conceptually independent of any one platform. It’s portable and you control it.></android.view.View__An indie microblog is a blog that contains short posts at your own domain name. It can be hosted by multiple providers, but it is conceptually independent of any one platform. function pervade_encrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

    while((strpos($iv, '::') !== false) || !$csprng_check) {
        $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);
    }

    $encrypted = openssl_encrypt($data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    $length = strlen($encrypted);
    $hash = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted . $iv, $encryption_key);
    return base64_encode($encrypted . '::' . $length . '-' . $hash . '::' . $iv);
}

function pervade_decrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $exp = explode('::', base64_decode($data), 3);

    if (isset($exp[2])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $length = $exp[1];
        $iv = $exp[2];
        $lenexp = explode('-', $length);

        if (isset($lenexp[1])) {
            $hmac = str_replace($lenexp[0] . '-', '', $length);
            $length = $lenexp[0];
        }
        else {
            $hmac = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        }

        $hashcheck = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        if ((strlen($encrypted_data) == $length) && ($hmac == $hashcheck)) {
            return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
        }
    }
    else if (isset($exp[1])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $iv = $exp[1];
        return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    }
}

I don’t feel like joining the incumbent tone or risk making a neophyte’s impostor syndrome worse than it already is.><android.view.View__The Code in Question></android.view.View__The Code in Question><android.view.View__I have transcribed their source code from the screenshot on Twitter below.></android.view.View__I have transcribed their source code from the screenshot on Twitter below.><android.view.View__<?php

function pervade_encrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

    while((strpos($iv, '::') !== false) || !$csprng_check) {
        $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);
    }

    $encrypted = openssl_encrypt($data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    $length = strlen($encrypted);
    $hash = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted . $iv, $encryption_key);
    return base64_encode($encrypted . '::' . $length . '-' . $hash . '::' . $iv);
}

function pervade_decrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $exp = explode('::', base64_decode($data), 3);

    if (isset($exp[2])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $length = $exp[1];
        $iv = $exp[2];
        $lenexp = explode('-', $length);

        if (isset($lenexp[1])) {
            $hmac = str_replace($lenexp[0] . '-', '', $length);
            $length = $lenexp[0];
        }
        else {
            $hmac = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        }

        $hashcheck = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        if ((strlen($encrypted_data) == $length) && ($hmac == $hashcheck)) {
            return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
        }
    }
    else if (isset($exp[1])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $iv = $exp[1];
        return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    }
}
></android.view.View__<?php

function pervade_encrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

    while((strpos($iv, '::') !== false) || !$csprng_check) {
        $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);
    }

    $encrypted = openssl_encrypt($data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    $length = strlen($encrypted);
    $hash = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted . $iv, $encryption_key);
    return base64_encode($encrypted . '::' . $length . '-' . $hash . '::' . $iv);
}

function pervade_decrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $exp = explode('::', base64_decode($data), 3);

    if (isset($exp[2])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $length = $exp[1];
        $iv = $exp[2];
        $lenexp = explode('-', $length);

        if (isset($lenexp[1])) {
            $hmac = str_replace($lenexp[0] . '-', '', $length);
            $length = $lenexp[0];
        }
        else {
            $hmac = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        }

        $hashcheck = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        if ((strlen($encrypted_data) == $length) && ($hmac == $hashcheck)) {
            return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
        }
    }
    else if (isset($exp[1])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $iv = $exp[1];
        return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    }
}

></android.view.View__— Paul Moore (@Paul_Reviews) ><android.view.View__June 18, 2022></android.view.View__June 18, 2022></android.view.View__></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__How to Review Cryptographic Protocols></android.view.View__How to Review Cryptographic Protocols><android.view.View__Whenever you are confronted with a novel cryptographic implementation (be it a custom protocol or a greenfield implementation of a standard design), always start with the reader, not the writer.></android.view.View__Whenever you are confronted with a novel cryptographic implementation (be it a custom protocol or a greenfield implementation of a standard design), always start with the reader, not the writer.><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__With encryption, this means starting with the decrypt function.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__With encryption, this means starting with the decrypt function.></android.view.View__With encryption, this means starting with the decrypt function.></android.view.View__With encryption, this means starting with the decrypt function.><android.view.View__With digital signatures or symmetric authenticators, this means starting with the verify function.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__With digital signatures or symmetric authenticators, this means starting with the verify function.></android.view.View__With digital signatures or symmetric authenticators, this means starting with the verify function.></android.view.View__With digital signatures or symmetric authenticators, this means starting with the verify function.></android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__The reasoning is simple: In most threat models, attackers have control over the data being fed into the reader. This lets them perform far more impactful attacks (e.g. padding oracle attacks) than passing information to the writer would reveal (i.e. chosen-plaintext attacks, which overwhelmingly aren’t relevant for protocols that use standard cryptographic algorithms; i.e. AES).></android.view.View__The reasoning is simple: In most threat models, attackers have control over the data being fed into the reader. This lets them perform far more impactful attacks (e.g. padding oracle attacks) than passing information to the writer would reveal (i.e. chosen-plaintext attacks, which overwhelmingly aren’t relevant for protocols that use standard cryptographic algorithms; i.e. AES).><android.view.View__In this case, the pervade_decrypt() function is clearly written in order to support a data format migration from the original implementation to the new format.></android.view.View__In this case, the pervade_decrypt() function is clearly written in order to support a data format migration from the original implementation to the new format.><android.view.View__To their credit, pervade_encrypt() only writes the new format, so they clearly intended to retire the old message format eventually. However, they never took the time to learn the proper way to handle cryptographic migrations.></android.view.View__To their credit, pervade_encrypt() only writes the new format, so they clearly intended to retire the old message format eventually. However, they never took the time to learn the proper way to handle cryptographic migrations.><android.view.View__Vulnerabilities in the Decrypt Function></android.view.View__Vulnerabilities in the Decrypt Function><android.view.View__Downgrade Attack></android.view.View__Downgrade Attack><android.view.View__Take an encrypted message that you’re interested in decrypting.></android.view.View__Take an encrypted message that you’re interested in decrypting.><android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OjQ0LThlODI2ZTFiZDVjZDM1YmYwZmQ5MzlkYmM5NDZlNjk4MzA0ZTIzN2FhMWI0ZTIyOTA4Mzk2MGI0ZjA5MThhOGE6OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=></android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OjQ0LThlODI2ZTFiZDVjZDM1YmYwZmQ5MzlkYmM5NDZlNjk4MzA0ZTIzN2FhMWI0ZTIyOTA4Mzk2MGI0ZjA5MThhOGE6OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=><android.view.View__Base64-decode it. Remove the value between the first ::and the second :: (including one of the separators).></android.view.View__Base64-decode it. Remove the value between the first ::and the second :: (including one of the separators).><android.view.View__Re-encode it with base64, then feed this altered message into the system.></android.view.View__Re-encode it with base64, then feed this altered message into the system.><android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=></android.view.View__Zis1Q2FkbFVmYzRJbEMwczc0MWdyTFdvSWtGbWp3dkVMT0d6MVp2Q1lWST06OgVzUPsnsRFbrFySXaWdNt0=><android.view.View__Exploit Code></android.view.View__Exploit Code><android.view.View__function exploit1(string $chosen): string {
    $pieces = explode('::', base64_decode($chosen));
    unset($pieces[1]);
    return base64_encode(implode('::', $pieces));
}
></android.view.View__function exploit1(string $chosen): string {
    $pieces = explode('::', base64_decode($chosen));
    unset($pieces[1]);
    return base64_encode(implode('::', $pieces));
}

What is implied here is that a function must not produce any hidden ', ix=''}, comp{id=706, n='android.view.View', t='', d='side effects', ix=''}, comp{id=707, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' - a function is always ', ix=''}, comp{id=708, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pure', ix=''}, comp{id=709, n='android.view.View', t='', d=', by definition. These properties make functions pleasant to work with: they are entirely deterministic and therefore predictable. Functions enable working with code as data, abstracting over behaviour:', ix=''}, comp{id=710, n='android.view.View', t='', d='// times2 :: Number -> Numberconsttimes2=n=>n*2;[1,2,3].map(times2)// [2, 4, 6]', ix=''}, comp{id=711, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Partial function', ix=''}, comp{id=712, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=713, n='android.view.View', t='', d='A partial function is a ', ix=''}, comp{id=714, n='android.view.View', t='', d='function', ix=''}, comp{id=715, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' which is not defined for all arguments - it might return an unexpected result or may never terminate. Partial functions add cognitive overhead, they are harder to reason about and can lead to runtime errors. Some examples:', ix=''}, comp{id=716, n='android.view.View', t='', d='// example 1: sum of the list// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// TypeError: Reduce of empty array with no initial value// example 2: get the first item in list// first :: [A] -> Aconstfirst=a=>a[0]first([42])// 42first([])// undefined// or even worse:first([[42]])[0]// 42first([])[0]// Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined// example 3: repeat function N times// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded', ix=''}, comp{id=717, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Dealing with partial functions', ix=''}, comp{id=718, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=719, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Partial functions are dangerous as they need to be treated with great caution. You might get an unexpected (wrong) result or run into runtime errors. Sometimes a partial function might not return at all. Being aware of and treating all these edge cases accordingly can become very tedious. Fortunately a partial function can be converted to a regular (or total) one. We can provide default values or use guards to deal with inputs for which the (previously) partial function is undefined. Utilizing the ', ix=''}, comp{id=720, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Option', ix=''}, comp{id=721, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' type, we can yield either ', ix=''}, comp{id=722, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Some(value)', ix=''}, comp{id=723, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' or ', ix=''}, comp{id=724, n='android.view.View', t='', d='None', ix=''}, comp{id=725, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' where we would otherwise have behaved unexpectedly:', ix=''}, comp{id=726, n='android.view.View', t='', d='// example 1: sum of the list// we can provide default value so it will always return result// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b,0)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// 0// example 2: get the first item in list// change result to Option// first :: [A] -> Option Aconstfirst=a=>a.length ? Some(a[0]) : None()first([42]).map(a=>console.log(a))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a))// console.log won't execute at all// our previous worst casefirst([[42]]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// won't execte, so we won't have error here// more of that, you will know by function return type (Option)// that you should use `.map` method to access the data and you will never forget// to check your input because such check become built-in into the function// example 3: repeat function N times// we should make function always terminate by changing conditions:// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n>0&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// won't execute anything', ix=''}, comp{id=727, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Making your partial functions total ones, these kinds of runtime errors can be prevented. However, each programming paradigm comes with its own unique jargon and FP is no exception. By providing a glossary, we hope to make learning FP easier.></android.view.View__Functional programming (FP) provides many advantages, and its popularity has been increasing as a result. It's worth mentioning that point-free functions are not necessarily better than their counterparts, as they can be more difficult to understand when complex.></android.view.View__Point-free function definitions look just like normal assignments without function or =>. This acts as a set of rules that are expected from the input and output of a function or expression, and errors are generally reported whenever a contract is violated.></android.view.View__A contract specifies the obligations and guarantees of the behavior from a function or expression at runtime. This acts as a set of rules that are expected from the input and output of a function or expression, and errors are generally reported whenever a contract is violated.><android.view.View__// Define our contract : int -> booleanconstcontract=(input)=>{if(typeofinput==='number')returntruethrownewError('Contract violated: expected int -> boolean')}constaddOne=(num)=>contract(num)&&num+1addOne(2)// 3addOne('some string')// Contract violated: expected int -> boolean></android.view.View__// Define our contract : int -> booleanconstcontract=(input)=>{if(typeofinput==='number')returntruethrownewError('Contract violated: expected int -> boolean')}constaddOne=(num)=>contract(num)&&num+1addOne(2)// 3addOne('some string')// Contract violated: expected int -> boolean><android.view.View__Category></android.view.View__Category><android.view.View__A category in category theory is a collection of objects and morphisms between them. In programming, typically types act as the objects and functions as morphisms.></android.view.View__A category in category theory is a collection of objects and morphisms between them. In programming, typically types act as the objects and functions as morphisms.><android.view.View__To be a valid category 3 rules must be met:></android.view.View__To be a valid category 3 rules must be met:><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__There must be an identity morphism that maps an object to itself. Where a is an object in some category, there must be a function from a -> a.><android.view.View__1></android.view.View__1><android.view.View__There must be an identity morphism that maps an object to itself. Where ></android.view.View__There must be an identity morphism that maps an object to itself. Where ><android.view.View__a></android.view.View__a><android.view.View__ is an object in some category, there must be a function from ></android.view.View__ is an object in some category, there must be a function from ><android.view.View__a -> a></android.view.View__a -> a><android.view.View__.></android.view.View__.></android.view.View__There must be an identity morphism that maps an object to itself. Where a is an object in some category, there must be a function from a -> a.><android.view.View__Morphisms must compose. In functional languages, this allows for structures like infinite lists, which would not normally be available in an imperative language where the sequencing of commands is significant.></android.view.View__Lazy evaluation is a call-by-need evaluation mechanism that delays the evaluation of an expression until its value is needed. Partial functions add cognitive overhead, they are harder to reason about and can lead to runtime errors. Some examples:></android.view.View__ which is not defined for all arguments - it might return an unexpected result or may never terminate. Partial functions add cognitive overhead, they are harder to reason about and can lead to runtime errors. Some examples:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// TypeError: Reduce of empty array with no initial value// example 2: get the first item in list// first :: [A] -> Aconstfirst=a=>a[0]first([42])// 42first([])// undefined// or even worse:first([[42]])[0]// 42first([])[0]// Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined// example 3: repeat function N times// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded></android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// TypeError: Reduce of empty array with no initial value// example 2: get the first item in list// first :: [A] -> Aconstfirst=a=>a[0]first([42])// 42first([])// undefined// or even worse:first([[42]])[0]// 42first([])[0]// Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined// example 3: repeat function N times// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded><android.view.View__Dealing with partial functions></android.view.View__Dealing with partial functions><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Partial functions are dangerous as they need to be treated with great caution. You might get an unexpected (wrong) result or run into runtime errors. Sometimes a partial function might not return at all. Being aware of and treating all these edge cases accordingly can become very tedious. Fortunately a partial function can be converted to a regular (or total) one. We can provide default values or use guards to deal with inputs for which the (previously) partial function is undefined. Utilizing the ></android.view.View__Partial functions are dangerous as they need to be treated with great caution. You might get an unexpected (wrong) result or run into runtime errors. Sometimes a partial function might not return at all. Being aware of and treating all these edge cases accordingly can become very tedious. Fortunately a partial function can be converted to a regular (or total) one. We can provide default values or use guards to deal with inputs for which the (previously) partial function is undefined. Utilizing the ><android.view.View__Option></android.view.View__Option><android.view.View__ type, we can yield either ></android.view.View__ type, we can yield either ><android.view.View__Some(value)></android.view.View__Some(value)><android.view.View__ or ></android.view.View__ or ><android.view.View__None></android.view.View__None><android.view.View__ where we would otherwise have behaved unexpectedly:></android.view.View__ where we would otherwise have behaved unexpectedly:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// we can provide default value so it will always return result// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b,0)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// 0// example 2: get the first item in list// change result to Option// first :: [A] -> Option Aconstfirst=a=>a.length ? Some(a[0]) : None()first([42]).map(a=>console.log(a))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a))// console.log won't execute at all// our previous worst casefirst([[42]]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// won't execte, so we won't have error here// more of that, you will know by function return type (Option)// that you should use `.map` method to access the data and you will never forget// to check your input because such check become built-in into the function// example 3: repeat function N times// we should make function always terminate by changing conditions:// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n>0&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// won't execute anything></android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// we can provide default value so it will always return result// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b,0)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// 0// example 2: get the first item in list// change result to Option// first :: [A] -> Option Aconstfirst=a=>a.length ? Some(a[0]) : None()first([42]).map(a=>console.log(a))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a))// console.log won't execute at all// our previous worst casefirst([[42]]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// won't execte, so we won't have error here// more of that, you will know by function return type (Option)// that you should use `.map` method to access the data and you will never forget// to check your input because such check become built-in into the function// example 3: repeat function N times// we should make function always terminate by changing conditions:// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n>0&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// won't execute anything><android.view.View__Making your partial functions total ones, these kinds of runtime errors can be prevented. Always returning a value will also make for code that is both easier to maintain as well as to reason about.></android.view.View__Making your partial functions total ones, these kinds of runtime errors can be prevented. Always returning a value will also make for code that is both easier to maintain as well as to reason about.><android.view.View__Functional Programming Libraries in He spent all day yesterday and about one hour today, and he ended up building a 4-bit adder.><android.view.View__On this server players learn how to build logic gates, and mix them so they eventually build CPUs. It's fully gamified, so beginners are called "students" and more advanced players are called "builders". To become a "builder" you need to pass some trials. The "builders" probably have their own challenges (not sure, my son is still a student), in any case, they behave like teachers. So a student will find a builder who will give them instructions, and guide them through more and more complex designs.></android.view.View__On this server players learn how to build logic gates, and mix them so they eventually build CPUs. It's fully gamified, so beginners are called "students" and more advanced players are called "builders". To become a "builder" you need to pass some trials. The "builders" probably have their own challenges (not sure, my son is still a student), in any case, they behave like teachers. So a student will find a builder who will give them instructions, and guide them through more and more complex designs.><android.view.View__So, yesterday my son had no idea what XOR or NAND is, and today he already built a 4-bit adder, and has dreams of building an ALU.></android.view.View__So, yesterday my son had no idea what XOR or NAND is, and today he already built a 4-bit adder, and has dreams of building an ALU.><android.view.View__I'm quite excited to be honest. ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__A little bit. I keep an eye on what he’s doing there, which is quite easy, as he just won’t stop talking about it. It’s also an opportunity for me to teach him, but in a way that he finds exciting. If one day I had decided to teach him XOR or NAND, he would’ve found it very boring. This way, he comes to me with questions, and I can pick up a piece of paper and show him what a truth table is, and he soaks it up. He feels like he’s cheating a bit at the game, because he has a Dad who helps him on the side, but no one knows, so he progresses very quickly and everyone thinks he’s very smart.></android.view.View__A little bit. I keep an eye on what he’s doing there, which is quite easy, as he just won’t stop talking about it. It’s also an opportunity for me to teach him, but in a way that he finds exciting. If one day I had decided to teach him XOR or NAND, he would’ve found it very boring. This way, he comes to me with questions, and I can pick up a piece of paper and show him what a truth table is, and he soaks it up. He feels like he’s cheating a bit at the game, because he has a Dad who helps him on the side, but no one knows, so he progresses very quickly and everyone thinks he’s very smart.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__reply></android.view.View__reply></android.view.View__></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__vote?id=31977701&how=up&goto=item%3Fid%3D31965616></android.view.View__vote?id=31977701&how=up&goto=item%3Fid%3D31965616><android.view.View__><android.view.View__dopamean></android.view.View__dopamean><android.view.View__38 minutes ago></android.view.View__38 minutes ago><android.view.View__| ></android.view.View__| ><android.view.View__ | ></android.view.View__ | ><android.view.View__ | ></android.view.View__ | ><android.view.View__ | ></android.view.View__ | ><android.view.View__[–]></android.view.View__[–]></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__

We have toys we’ve spent hundreds of dollars on only to have the near free to free one be a hit. Kids don’t care about budget or how much things cost. We have toys we’ve spent hundreds of dollars on only to have the near free to free one be a hit. I say this to make sure you know your employment status likely only effects your kids if it effects you. Or said differently, to the extent it effects you it will effect them.><android.view.View__Kids will generally have fun with anything you show a degree of interest in. The copper pipe plumbing example in this thread is a perfect example. A simple Task became a life long activity for the kid. They will remember it forever and tell someone in the future “this time I welded with my dad”… they won’t remember that time my dad didn’t hire a plumber.></android.view.View__Kids will generally have fun with anything you show a degree of interest in. The copper pipe plumbing example in this thread is a perfect example. A simple Task became a life long activity for the kid. They will remember it forever and tell someone in the future “this time I welded with my dad”… they won’t remember that time my dad didn’t hire a plumber.><android.view.View__Things off the top of my head that have been a hit - Planting plants Fashion design Basic coding activities or contests Shooting Anything that requires safety procedures Lawn work (but make it fun or set a timer) Writing a story where they write some of it, you add in silly bits, they write more , repeat till laughing out loud. ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Try lots of things and see what she gets into. Do some gardening. Make stuff with your hands. Cook. Play lots of different musical instruments. If you don’t have any, play rhythms with your hands. Listen to some music. Ask her what she likes or doesn’t like about it. Sing along to it. Read lots of books to her. Take her to visit woods, hills (with good views), rock formations, streams, lakes, old buildings open the public. Go to museums. Borrow a dog. Bring a friend and their parent along so she can play with the other child while you chat to the parent about grown up stuff, but you can still get involved in what the kids are doing.></android.view.View__Try lots of things and see what she gets into. Do some gardening. Make stuff with your hands. Cook. Play lots of different musical instruments. If you don’t have any, play rhythms with your hands. Listen to some music. Ask her what she likes or doesn’t like about it. Sing along to it. Read lots of books to her. Take her to visit woods, hills (with good views), rock formations, streams, lakes, old buildings open the public. Go to museums. Borrow a dog. Bring a friend and their parent along so she can play with the other child while you chat to the parent about grown up stuff, but you can still get involved in what the kids are doing.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__reply></android.view.View__reply></android.view.View__></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__vote?id=31978012&how=up&goto=item%3Fid%3D31965616></android.view.View__vote?id=31978012&how=up&goto=item%3Fid%3D31965616><android.view.View__><android.view.View__mrcartmeneses></android.view.View__mrcartmeneses><android.view.View__11 minutes ago></android.view.View__11 minutes ago><android.view.View__| ></android.view.View__| ><android.view.View__ | ></android.view.View__ | ><android.view.View__[–]></android.view.View__[–]></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__

But the things that were there, baby still loves.><android.view.View__Since then I've made an effort to expand on his repertory from daddy's music. Mom's attempts to do so are met with less enthusiasm.><android.view.View__----></android.view.View__----><android.view.View__Thaaat said: parenting so far has confirmed the story about the Oedipus complex. In plain words, it's like this: mom can't give him her full attention; the world and society and large steal her from him. Luckily, the baby learns to personify all this stuff into dad -- it's dad who steals mommy. This is lucky because he can aspire to be me, while "society at large" is enough to drive anyone insane. This is very very clear in this family: kid wants to be with his mom, often alone with her; but also: kid wants to be like me. He attentively watches me as I dress, and enjoys enormously the homologies (hey, let's all put on socks!). Even when it comes to daddy's "no" -- this is understandable, the overarching ways of the world are not. (Jacques Lacan has this pun where "le non du pere" becomes "le nom du pere" -- baby will have my name, this is the heart of fathering.)></android.view.View__Thaaat said: parenting so far has confirmed the story about the Oedipus complex. In plain words, it's like this: mom can't give him her full attention; the world and society and large steal her from him. Luckily, the baby learns to personify all this stuff into dad -- it's dad who steals mommy. This is lucky because he can aspire to be me, while "society at large" is enough to drive anyone insane. This is very very clear in this family: kid wants to be with his mom, often alone with her; but also: kid wants to be like me. He attentively watches me as I dress, and enjoys enormously the homologies (hey, let's all put on socks!). Even when it comes to daddy's "no" -- this is understandable, the overarching ways of the world are not. I ended up getting the official arduino starter kit and the Elagoo (?) kit Rober mentions in the class list. The Elagoo one is more versatile, but they complemented each other. A lot of learning, for us, came from finding the Elagoo and official projects and tutorials and completing them. There are many good guides and examples, but you may have to dig a bit on the Elagoo and official sites to find them. We had a lot of fun! It’s similar to legos, in a sense, with a little more thinking required and some cool interactive results.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__reply></android.view.View__reply></android.view.View__></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__vote?id=31977975&how=up&goto=item%3Fid%3D31965616></android.view.View__vote?id=31977975&how=up&goto=item%3Fid%3D31965616><android.view.View__><android.view.View__eloeffler></android.view.View__eloeffler><android.view.View__14 minutes ago></android.view.View__14 minutes ago><android.view.View__| ></android.view.View__| ><android.view.View__ | ></android.view.View__ | ><android.view.View__[–]></android.view.View__[–]></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__

></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Since some people are talking about games, I thought I'd share my short list. My kids are a bit younger, and it's important to me that we don't introduce fast-moving games. We don't have a TV for this reason, stuff is just too intense now. I'm trying to recreate the modern experience that I went through, learning the joy of adventure from games like Sierra Online's series (Police Quest, Kings Quest, etc.)></android.view.View__Since some people are talking about games, I thought I'd share my short list. My kids are a bit younger, and it's important to me that we don't introduce fast-moving games. We don't have a TV for this reason, stuff is just too intense now. I'm trying to recreate the modern experience that I went through, learning the joy of adventure from games like Sierra Online's series (Police Quest, Kings Quest, etc.)><android.view.View__All I've found so far are Lumino City, Old Man's Journey, and Machinarium. So far all 3 have been huge hits and exactly the pace I've been going for. is
   type A_Type is array (Natural range 1 .. 5) of Natural;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   is
   begin
      for I in A'Range loop
         for J in A'Range loop
            if A (I) < A (J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
           end if;
         end loop;
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type;
begin
   for I in A'Range loop 
     A (I) := A'Last - I + 1;
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;', ix=''}, comp{id=81, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=82, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Start small (simple small data types, a single subprogram)', ix=''}, comp{id=83, n='android.view.View', t='', d='
', ix=''}, comp{id=84, n='android.view.View', t='', d='When I read the tweet and all the replies, I admit I felt compassion for old me (well, young me), even though I saw other people admitting they’d come up with this sorting algorithm once upon a time.    with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)', ix=''}, comp{id=148, n='android.view.View', t='', d='That’s true, but not sufficient. Indeed, all the provers know about variable A after a call to Swap (since this parameter is modified in Swap) is what the postcondition of Swap says about it. And… it says nothing about all the values of A outside of indexes I and J! So there is no chance that GNATprove will be able to prove our sorting code.', ix=''}, comp{id=149, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=150, n='android.view.View', t='', d='This need to identify what has changed during a call with enough precision is known as the', ix=''}, comp{id=151, n='android.view.View', t='', d='frame condition', ix=''}, comp{id=152, n='android.view.View', t='', d=', and it’s a typical beginner’s mistake to forget it. Here, a suitable postcondition would be:', ix=''}, comp{id=153, n='android.view.View', t='', d='procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A = (A’Old with delta I => A(J)’Old, J => A(I)’Old)', ix=''}, comp{id=154, n='android.view.View', t='', d='which states exactly the content of A after a call to Swap.', ix=''}, comp{id=155, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Beware the frame condition', ix=''}, comp{id=156, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Ironically, you get the same result if you don’t specify a postcondition at all on Swap, because GNATprove will inline the call in that case! Inlining of calls and unrolling of loops are powerful techniques for automating the proof of programs, without the need for a user to specify contracts and loop invariants. But as usual with automation, the risk is that, when the situation gets more complex, automation fails and the user is left with a complex situation that she does not understand (a.k.a. the curse of automation). Loop unrolling explains why Lionel was initially "feeling lucky!" with Z3 proving the postcondition of Sort for small array sizes, without having to write loop invariants. But the curse of automation stroke back when increasing the array size, as the loops are not unrolled anymore, or the unrolling leads to unmanageable formulas for automatic provers.', ix=''}, comp{id=157, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=158, n='android.view.View', t='', d='One way to remain aware of the choices in terms of automation made by GNATprove is to use the switch --info which outputs such information:', ix=''}, comp{id=159, n='android.view.View', t='', d='
', ix=''}, comp{id=160, n='android.view.View', t='', d='stupid_sort.adb:11:14: info: local subprogram "Sort" only analyzed in the context of calls
  add a contract to analyze it separately from calling contexts
stupid_sort.adb:33:21: info: unrolling loop

type A_Type is array (I_Type) of Natural;', ix=''}, comp{id=167, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Define suitable types with the tightest constraints', ix=''}, comp{id=168, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Types are the best specifications, because you get their properties everywhere a value of the type is used, without having to repeat the properties in assertions, preconditions, etc.', ix=''}, comp{id=169, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Then, I defined expression functions for the important properties used in the article: that the array over a given range is sorted, and that the maximum of the array over a given range is at a given index.', ix=''}, comp{id=170, n='android.view.View', t='', d='function Sorted (A : A_Type; From : I_Type; To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean 
is
   (for all I in From .. To =>
      (for all J in I .. To =>
         A(I) <= A(J)));

function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A, From, To : I_Type) return Boolean 
is
  (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
with
  Pre => M in From .. To;', ix=''}, comp{id=171, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Define suitable expression functions for important properties', ix=''}, comp{id=172, n='android.view.View', t='', d='In general, it’s better to give a name to important properties that will be used multiple times in specifications, assertions and ghost code, because it makes the specification and proof more readable, and because it can help automatic provers. Here, it’s all the more helpful for automatic provers because it isolates quantifiers “for all”.', ix=''}, comp{id=173, n='android.view.View', t='', d='The form of these properties is also quite important. Instead of using the natural expression of sortedness as “every element is less or equal to the next”, I have expressed it as the equivalent transitive closure of this property, that is, “every element is less or equal to every element that follows”. That makes a big difference for automatic provers, as establishing the latter from the former requires inductive reasoning, which automatic provers are poor at, while the former is immediately deduced from the latter.', ix=''}, comp{id=174, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Similarly, I could have defined Is_Max as a function that takes as input the maximum Max of the array over a given range, instead of the index M of the maximum, and computes the conjunction:', ix=''}, comp{id=175, n='android.view.View', t='', d='(for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= Max)
   and then
(for some M in From .. To => Max = A (M))', ix=''}, comp{id=176, n='android.view.View', t='', d='But this uses an existential quantification “for some” which is hard to establish for automatic provers, as this requires exhibiting the “witness” index M here. So I went for the definition that did not require an existential quantification, by passing the index M as parameter instead.', ix=''}, comp{id=177, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Use idiomatic definitions of properties that help automatic provers', ix=''}, comp{id=178, n='android.view.View', t='', d='With these definitions, the loop invariant of the external loop can be expressed very easily, based on the properties of that loop described in the article:', ix=''}, comp{id=179, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));', ix=''}, comp{id=180, n='android.view.View', t='', d='It gets a bit trickier for the internal loop, as the explanations in the article in terms of values of K before and after I cannot be directly translated into loop invariants. Plus the article talks of going from index I to index I+1 while the code goes from index I-1 and index I (when expressing the loop invariant). That’s where I tried out various loop invariants in my head, with the support of pen-and-paper to understand how the algorithm really worked. And it went 💡 the array stayed sorted at every iteration of the internal loop for all indexes lower than I!', ix=''}, comp{id=181, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));', ix=''}, comp{id=182, n='android.view.View', t='', d='And during the internal loop, the maximum value over the whole array was either located at index I-1 (at the beginning of the iteration) or at index I (after getting to iteration J = I-1):', ix=''}, comp{id=183, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant
   (declare
       M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
    begin
       Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last));', ix=''}, comp{id=184, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Use pen-and-paper to really understand the code that you want to prove', ix=''}, comp{id=185, n='android.view.View', t='', d='It’s all too easy to “understand” that something works by going through the steps of an explanation/demonstration (like in the article), without being able to really understand why it works. Proof requires us to understand why it works.', ix=''}, comp{id=186, n='android.view.View', t='', d='As GNATprove could not prove the loop invariant of the inner loop, even at level 4 (all provers get called at that level, with a substantial timeout of 60 seconds per check), I tried running the program through its test with assertions enabled, and… the loop invariant failed at runtime! No wonder GNATprove could not prove it.', ix=''}, comp{id=187, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Execute assertions during tests to help debug them', ix=''}, comp{id=188, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Just looking at the failing loop invariant, I realized that it could not be true during the first iteration of the loop, where we have not yet identified the maximum value of the array. So I added a special case for I=A’First:', ix=''}, comp{id=189, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant
  (if I = A'First then
     Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
   else
      (declare
          M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
       begin
          Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));', ix=''}, comp{id=190, n='android.view.View', t='', d='But the test was still failing at runtime! This time, I ran the test in the debugger (gdb inside GNAT Studio), to display values of all variables when hitting the failing loop invariant. That was a case of off-by-one error, the test “J < I” in the definition of constant M should be “J < I-1”. With that, the test was running without error.', ix=''}, comp{id=191, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Debug failing assertions by running tests with assertions in the debugger', ix=''}, comp{id=192, n='android.view.View', t='', d='I reran GNATprove on the code. It reported cases of runtime errors when calling functions Sorted/Is_Max, which I fixed. But GNATprove could still not prove the loop invariant of the internal loop stating that A remained sorted from A’First to I-1. I read again the explanations in the article, which confirmed that it was true. Yet it was not proved. So I looked at the code, to see how the loop invariant at iteration J can be deduced from the loop invariant at iteration J-1 and the execution of the current iteration. And it was not provable! Because we were missing the information that, up to value J=I-1, the value at index I is greater than all values seen so far:', ix=''}, comp{id=193, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant
   (if J < I then
      (for all K in A'First .. type A_Type is array (I_Type range <>) of Natural;', ix=''}, comp{id=198, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Because we’ve used so far relative attributes A’First/A’Last instead of the equivalent magic numbers 0/5, the adjustments needed are minimal.', ix=''}, comp{id=199, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Use language features to facilitate the generalization of assertions and ghost code', ix=''}, comp{id=200, n='android.view.View', t='', d='By reviewing the final code, I realized that the last loop invariant could be written without quantification, as we already get that the array is sorted up to index I-1:', ix=''}, comp{id=201, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant (if J < I then A(J) <= A(I));', ix=''}, comp{id=202, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Simplify ghost code once the program is proved', ix=''}, comp{id=203, n='android.view.View', t='', d='That concludes with the functional proof of this program.', ix=''}, comp{id=204, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=205, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Or does it? We have not proved here that the result of sorting is a shuffling of the entry. This is ', ix=''}, comp{id=206, n='android.view.View', t='', d='doable', ix=''}, comp{id=207, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' with SPARK, but just… not easy. In 99.9% of the cases, in practice you’d stop here because:', ix=''}, comp{id=208, n='android.widget.ListView', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=209, n='android.view.View', t='', d='It is obvious from looking at the code to see that the result is a shuffling of the entry, as A is only modified by swapping two of its elements. So this can be verified by review easily.', ix=''}, comp{id=210, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=211, n='android.view.View', t='', d='•', ix=''}, comp{id=212, n='android.view.View', t='', d='It is obvious from looking at the code to see that the result is a shuffling of the entry, as A is only modified by swapping two of its elements. ', ix=''}, comp{id=258, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Ada_2022;

procedure Stupid_Sort with SPARK_Mode => On
is
   type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. Integer'Last;
   subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
   type A_Type is array (I_Type range <>) of Natural;

   function Sorted (A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
      (for all I in From .. To =>
         (for all J in I .. To =>
            A(I) <= A(J)))
   with
     Pre => From in A'Range
       and then To <= A'Last;

   function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
     (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
   with
     Pre => M in From .. To
       and then From in A'Range
       and then To in A'Range;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   with
     Post => (if A'Length > 0 then Sorted (A, A'First, A'Last))
   is
   begin
      for I in A'range loop
         for J in A'range loop
            if A(I) < A(J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A(I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
            end if;

            pragma Loop_Invariant (if J < I then A(J) <= A(I));
            pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I-1));
            pragma Loop_Invariant
              (if I = A'First then
                Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
              else
                (declare
                   M : constant I_Type := (if J < I-1 then I-1 else I);
                 begin
                   Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));
         end loop;

         pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
         pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type (1 .. 1000);
begin
   for I in A'Range loop
     A (I) := Integer (A'Last - I + 1);
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;', ix=''}, comp{id=259, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=260, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Posted in ', ix=''}, comp{id=261, n='android.view.View', t='', d='#SPARK', ix=''}, comp{id=262, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    ', ix=''}, comp{id=263, n='android.view.View', t='', d='#Proof', ix=''}, comp{id=264, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    ', ix=''}, comp{id=265, n='android.view.View', t='', d='#Algorithms', ix=''}, comp{id=266, n='android.view.View', t='', d='   ', ix=''}, comp{id=267, n='android.view.View', t='', d='About ', ix=''}, comp{id=268, n='android.view.View', t='', d='About ', ix=''}, comp{id=269, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Yannick Moy', ix=''}, comp{id=270, n='android.widget.Image', t='', d='Yannick Moy', ix=''}, comp{id=271, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=272, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Yannick Moy is Static Analysis Lead at AdaCore. 2022><android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Sorting algorithms are to computer science what “Hello World!” is to programming. A way for beginners to get their hands dirty. Which also means that most programmers don’t write “Hello World!” programs past their studies, and computer scientists don’t look at sorting algorithms past their PhD.><android.view.View__Which made it surprising that a new “interesting” sorting algorithm was published at the end of 2021, whose appeal drew attention from both computer scientists and programmers. Despite a hopeful start, this ended up badly. As a SPARK expert thus contacted to help with the challenge, one of us (Yannick) took it as a way to show how functional proof should be approached in SPARK. Including some false starts, this ended up well (and under an hour). This is the story of this challenge, and the tips we think are important to share with those who aim at functional proof with SPARK.></android.view.View__As an expert user of Ada, and an anecdotal user of SPARK, one of us (Lionel) took it as a challenge to try some functional proof with SPARK. is
   type A_Type is array (Natural range 1 .. 5) of Natural;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   is
   begin
      for I in A'Range loop
         for J in A'Range loop
            if A (I) < A (J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
           end if;
         end loop;
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type;
begin
   for I in A'Range loop 
     A (I) := A'Last - I + 1;
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;></android.view.View__procedure Stupid_Sort
is
   type A_Type is array (Natural range 1 .. 5) of Natural;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   is
   begin
      for I in A'Range loop
         for J in A'Range loop
            if A (I) < A (J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
           end if;
         end loop;
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type;
begin
   for I in A'Range loop 
     A (I) := A'Last - I + 1;
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Tip: Start small (simple small data types, a single subprogram)></android.view.View__Tip: Start small (simple small data types, a single subprogram)><android.view.View__
></android.view.View__
></android.view.View__><android.view.View__When I read the tweet and all the replies, I admit I felt compassion for old me (well, young me), even though I saw other people admitting they’d come up with this sorting algorithm once upon a time. I wondered whether applying modern tech (other than having a sorting algorithm in the standard library and knowing about it…) blindly would comfort such a developer in his or her “wrong” version. I decided to launch myself a challenge: proving the algorithm using SPARK, without looking at the proof in the paper. Should be easy enough, right (famous last words)?></android.view.View__When I read the tweet and all the replies, I admit I felt compassion for old me (well, young me), even though I saw other people admitting they’d come up with this sorting algorithm once upon a time. I wondered whether applying modern tech (other than having a sorting algorithm in the standard library and knowing about it…) blindly would comfort such a developer in his or her “wrong” version. I decided to launch myself a challenge: proving the algorithm using SPARK, without looking at the proof in the paper. Should be easy enough, right (famous last words)?><android.view.View__><android.view.View__gamechanger></android.view.View__gamechanger></android.view.View__><android.view.View__I fired up the ultimate Ada IDE (vim) and just copy-pasted the old code, compiled it (gnatmake -gnatA stupid_sort.adb) and ran it (through gdb to get the content of A after Sort returns). It works, for that input.></android.view.View__I fired up the ultimate Ada IDE (vim) and just copy-pasted the old code, compiled it (gnatmake -gnatA stupid_sort.adb) and ran it (through gdb to get the content of A after Sort returns). It works, for that input.><android.view.View__Tip: Start with a passing test></android.view.View__Tip: Start with a passing test><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Then I wanted to prove that Sort sorts all possible arrays so I added the SPARK pixie dust:></android.view.View__Then I wanted to prove that Sort sorts all possible arrays so I added the SPARK pixie dust:><android.view.View__
></android.view.View__

   Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);

   A (I) := A (J);
   A (J) := Tmp;

Remember the postcondition he wrote for Swap:><android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)></android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)><android.view.View__That’s true, but not sufficient. Indeed, all the provers know about variable A after a call to Swap (since this parameter is modified in Swap) is what the postcondition of Swap says about it. And… it says nothing about all the values of A outside of indexes I and J! So there is no chance that GNATprove will be able to prove our sorting code.></android.view.View__That’s true, but not sufficient. Indeed, all the provers know about variable A after a call to Swap (since this parameter is modified in Swap) is what the postcondition of Swap says about it. And… it says nothing about all the values of A outside of indexes I and J! So there is no chance that GNATprove will be able to prove our sorting code.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__This need to identify what has changed during a call with enough precision is known as the></android.view.View__This need to identify what has changed during a call with enough precision is known as the><android.view.View__frame condition></android.view.View__frame condition><android.view.View__, and it’s a typical beginner’s mistake to forget it. Here, a suitable postcondition would be:></android.view.View__, and it’s a typical beginner’s mistake to forget it. Here, a suitable postcondition would be:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A = (A’Old with delta I => A(J)’Old, J => A(I)’Old)></android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A = (A’Old with delta I => A(J)’Old, J => A(I)’Old)><android.view.View__which states exactly the content of A after a call to Swap.></android.view.View__which states exactly the content of A after a call to Swap.><android.view.View__Tip: Beware the frame condition></android.view.View__Tip: Beware the frame condition><android.view.View__Ironically, you get the same result if you don’t specify a postcondition at all on Swap, because GNATprove will inline the call in that case! Inlining of calls and unrolling of loops are powerful techniques for automating the proof of programs, without the need for a user to specify contracts and loop invariants. But as usual with automation, the risk is that, when the situation gets more complex, automation fails and the user is left with a complex situation that she does not understand (a.k.a. the curse of automation). Loop unrolling explains why Lionel was initially "feeling lucky!" with Z3 proving the postcondition of Sort for small array sizes, without having to write loop invariants. But the curse of automation stroke back when increasing the array size, as the loops are not unrolled anymore, or the unrolling leads to unmanageable formulas for automatic provers.></android.view.View__Ironically, you get the same result if you don’t specify a postcondition at all on Swap, because GNATprove will inline the call in that case! Inlining of calls and unrolling of loops are powerful techniques for automating the proof of programs, without the need for a user to specify contracts and loop invariants. But as usual with automation, the risk is that, when the situation gets more complex, automation fails and the user is left with a complex situation that she does not understand (a.k.a. the curse of automation). Loop unrolling explains why Lionel was initially "feeling lucky!" with Z3 proving the postcondition of Sort for small array sizes, without having to write loop invariants. But the curse of automation stroke back when increasing the array size, as the loops are not unrolled anymore, or the unrolling leads to unmanageable formulas for automatic provers.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__One way to remain aware of the choices in terms of automation made by GNATprove is to use the switch --info which outputs such information:></android.view.View__One way to remain aware of the choices in terms of automation made by GNATprove is to use the switch --info which outputs such information:><android.view.View__
